jekyll	380	closed	27	csaunders	2011-08-07 15:23:54	901.23		+1		b'b" If you ever want to chat about it, I\'m hanging out in the #jekyll channel on freenode."'
jekyll	380	closed	28	csaunders	2011-08-07 15:23:54	18.15		+1		b'b" Internally liquid templates know about all their child . When I have spare time I\'ve been working on a patch to make it such that liquid templates can inform you about what other templates are they are including. With that information we can probably build a global lookup table that maps and build the dependency tree from there. This is what I have in mind in terms of that dependency tree: We\'d keep a manifest to the last successful compilation which contains hashes of all the files, and once we find a change just need to find out the files that depend on the changed file."'
jekyll	380	closed	29	parkr	2011-08-07 15:23:54	16.35		+1		b"b' @mattrCan you push up your branch? This will help our conversation here.'

b"b' R18n support for locale date formats'"

b'b" I\'ve added R18n support to use locale date formats. This includes a _locale/ folder that can be used to define the date_format and long_date_format. In the future this could also be used for other translations. Two new configuration parameters have became available:locale (translation_path (default: (
column11: \'_locale\')) Last: the default format used in tests (27 Jan 2011) is changed into 10/01/2010. It might be useful to include a _ by default?"'

column10: b'b" I\'m -1 on any out-of-the-box layout defaults. Jekyll should operate in obvious
column11: unsurprising ways
column12: and default layouts based on specifically named layout files is massively surprising (not to mention backwards incompatible). I\'m ok with adding the ability to set default layouts
column13: though
column14: but I think we should make it a power user feature
column15: and make it very flexible. If we\'re going to do it
column16: you should be able to set default layouts for given paths. Default layouts for sub-paths should override super-paths. For example
column17: if you want to default to for everything but posts
column18: and you want posts to default to
column19: then you could do: If you leave out the path
column20: then it would apply to all paths. This should also be pushed out to a post-1.0 release."'

column10: b'b\' Why are you going backwards? Sensible defaults for page and post layouts are quintessential "convention over configuration". Why would you want to revert to forcing every page to explicitly configure a layout? Defaulting to and for page and post layouts is about the least surprising thing imaginable. What is more surprising is when everyone makes up their own file name so there is no conventional pattern. Moving between different Jekyll sites one constantly has to ask
column11: what are the primary layouts for this site: page
column12: post
column13: main
column14: default
column15: standard
column16: layout
column17: page_layout
column18: post_layout
column19: layout_main
column20: etc.\''

column10: b'b\' @trans If you\\\'re moving from Jekyll pre-1.0 to Jekyll 1.0
column11: you\\\'ll be surprised. I\\\'d bet anything that\\\'d be true. The default should be unless explicitly set
column12: as it was. I was hesitant about accepting the page and post layout defaults in the first place
column13: seems that it was the wrong choice to accept it! This is ultimately @mojombo\\\'s call. Out-of-the-box layout defaults are "magic
column14:
and the less magic we introduce, the fewer frustrations are likely to occur.\''
jekyll	453	closed	21	tofumatt	2011-12-15 05:47:17	1.8	+1			b'b" So either I missed some documentation or it\'s not obvious, but I didn\'t know about the and defaults. I totally agree and think those are sane defaults and should be left in. Sorry for opening this can of worms."'
jekyll	453	closed	22	parkr	2011-12-15 05:47:17	3.23	+1			b'b" Don\'t be sorry, it\'s important. One thing I hate about frameworks like rails is how magical it is. It works if you dot your i\'s and cross your t\'s but will wreak havoc if you forget something or if our defaulting code breaks on an edge case. If I set my front-matter to... ... jekyll may default to post or page default even though I explicitly asked it not to. I\'d rather as the user to turn things on than to have to try to turn them off. I think generators are the solution here, not out-of-the-box layout defaults."'
jekyll	453	closed	23	mojombo	2011-12-15 05:47:17	25.73			+1	b'b\' @trans Jekyll is not Rails. Convention over configuration is not our motto. Simplicity and obviousness are what Jekyll cares about. Out of the box, Jekyll should be brutally obvious in how it functions. You ask Jekyll to apply a layout to a page or post and it does it. You don\\\'t ask it to apply a layout and it doesn\\\'t. Later on, when you realize that applying a default layout to a set of  would be better, I\\\'d love to support that and make it possible. Backwards compatibility is also extremely important for GitHub Pages, and I don\\\'t want this 1.0 release to turn into a shitshow of "why did my site totally break and do surprising things when all I did was push like normal?" Enabling out-of-the-box layout defaults will cause this. How many sites out there do you think already use as their posts layout? How many of them use as a layout file but don\\\'t want it applied to EVERY SINGLE PAGE? I\\\'m guessing it\\\'s non-zero, and the alternative of keeping Jekyll obvious but still allowing for default layouts is, in my mind, a better solution anyhow.\''

column14: posts across namespaces are separate but equal (although some are more equal than others)).  Here is an example:When adding a new page to their "projects"
column15: they have to add it to the menu.  If the project .md file was within the it could be iterated and automatically added to the menu and other pages which list all projects.\\\'Blog posts\\\' are traditionally akin to a newspaper article

column19: blog post

column10: b"b' Preloads directory_watcher glob'"

b"b' This fixes all the issues I have with auto-regeneration. But seeing how this is a elusive bug feedback and testing is welcome! What it does is simply to preload the directory before scanning it. Somehow this stops the initial repeated auto-regeneration events which may lead to an infinite loop of events. It also always does an initial build
column11: previously the initial build was triggered 0 or 7 times(No kidding...). It does not require the latest(broken) version of directory_watcher.'"

b"b' Converters can run before liquid is evaluated [#889]'"
b'b" (A response to #889) Specified converters can now be run before liquid tags are evaluated by including the method  . Tests and docs have been updated to reflect this
column11: and the converter has been added as a lowest-priority catch-all for pre-liquid converters. The new workflow is:1. Run pre-liquid converters2. Evaluate liquid tags3. Run post-liquid (default) converters Note that this means that posts may go through two different converters one pre-liquid and one post-liquid. Converters are added to the post-liquid queue by default. This means that if you don\'t add any pre-liquid converters
column12: behaviour should default to standard. Unit tests run fine on my machine
column13: and manual tests seem to show that everything is working well. Feedback appreciated."'

column13: or after. By default they\\\'ll run afterwards (as was the behaviour previously). now takes an argument (  or
column14: defaults to  ) and will only retrieve converters that are designed to run either before or after liquid tags are evaluated (depending on said argument). Since doesn\\\'t handle returns from well
column15: is the "backup" converter for the pre-liquid conversion call. (This also suggests that maybe _should_ be able to deal with returns from  ?) Does this explanation make sense? If you want I can add some comments to the class
column16: further expanding on its role.\''

column11: This pull request add a support for the [Rouge syntax highlighter]url  which is a nice alternative to Pygments. The test added pass on my machine. I\'m not familiar with Jekyll code so let me know if I should add or remove something. Thanks. Have a nice day."'

column10: b'b" I\'ve noticed that Pygments was a performance bottleneck on sites with a lot of highlighting. Have you made any benchmarks?"'
b'b" On the specific implementation in Jekyll no
column11: I haven\'t made any benchmarks but a Rouge\'s contributor has made it. See url  for details. "'

column10: b'b" According to the benchmark in that issue
column11: there is a 10% slowdown for JSON code
column12: and a 25% slowdown in Ruby code when Rouge is compared to
column13: which is what Jekyll uses. While I like the idea of using a pure Ruby syntax highlighter
column14: the additional performance hit is not worth it.  Also
column15: this PR is missing an update to our custom highlight liquid tag that also uses Pygments for syntax highlighting.  I\'m going to close this for the above reasons. If Rouge can meet \'s performance characteristics and all our existing uses of Pygments can be covered
column16: then I think it can be looked at again."'

column10: b"b' Permalink behavior changed in 1.0'"
b'b" **Edit:** TL;DR: In Jekyll 1.0.x
column11: the behavior of permalinks changed. If I have a page in a sub folder
column12: e.g.
column14: with a permalink of permalink: /bar
column15: pre 1.0.x
column16: the resulting URL would be / (available as //). Post 1.0
column17: a permalink of /bar/ in that same file
column18: now gets rendered as / (available at /bar/). Difference is it no longer respects sub folders. The way permalinks for subfolders has changed in 1.0. If this is intentional
column19: it should be documented as it is (potentially) a breaking change. Steps to reproduce:1.  2. Build site using Jekyll < 1.03. Build site using Jekyll Expected:In both builds
column20: the path should resolve to Actual:In Jekyll < 1.0 the site builds as expectedIn Jekyll This can potentially break some sites which rely on subfolders and the original permalink behavior to namespace permalinks.  If backwards compatibility wasn\'t a concern
column21: I\'d argue that the new behavior is slightly more intuitive
column22: as I\'ve been asked about use cases where developers wanted to organize pages in a certain directory structure and have paths resolve differently
column23: but could see valid arguments for both sides."'

b"b' Use valid css class names when pygments language contains invalid chars
column11: eg html+django'"

column10: b'b\' Pygments has some lexers that combine multiple languages and are referenced by name using the plus sign
column11: eg "html+django" is a valid lexer name. In the tag
column12: the lexer name also gets used as the CSS class name in the wrapping HTML block
column13: but the plus sign is invalid here. This change simply converts plus signs to minus signs
column14: to conform with valid CSS class names.\''

column10: b'b" I think we\'d want to normalize the lang elsewhere
column11: right? And I\'d love tests for this so we don\'t break it in the future. They\'re in  ."'

column10: b'b" Is it used as a CSS classname anywhere else? As far as Pygments goes it\'s doing the right thing
column11: so nothing needs to change there. As for tests I haven\'t written Ruby for a couple of years
column12: so I\'m a bit out of my depth there. Happy to give it a go but I\'d need some guidance."'

column10: b"b' Smoother upgrade path for 1.0.x permalinks'"
b'b" _Background: url  url After some discussions with @parkr
column11: @zachgersh
column12: and @sankage over in #jekyll
column13: it turns out the upgrade path for GitHub Pages isn\'t as clean as one may hope
column14: and could potentially cause a lot of pain for [a lot of users]url  without any action on their part
column15: something most users would not expect (or like). Assuming old permalink behavior is :skull: and new permalink behavior is :crown:
column16: here\'s what I propose. Glad to start submitting PR\'s if there\'s a :+1::## On the Jekyll core side of things:1. Create a flag
column17: which defaults to  2. Turning the flag to on in reverts to the old permalink behavior but throws a deprecation warning.3. Add a big red box to the [upgrading page]url 4. Plan to kill in a future version This would move new sites over to the new default
column18: and if a site breaks
column19: they can easily unbreak with a single config var (and would be gently pushed to upgrade their permalinks on each build).## On the Pages side of things:1. GitHub pages will set the default to but allow users to override via their (there\'s precedence for this in how pygments
column20: safe
column21: etc. are handled)2. Add a call out to [the help docs]url  This would mean that **we don\'t break any Pages sites** :tada: making basically zero pain for the user. The only potential pain point would be for users running 1.0.x locally
column22: which would have different permalink behavior by default.1. I\'d rather break sites locally
column23: then on Pages. There\'s much
column24: much
column25: much less downside2. A user running locally is going to be sophisticated enough to add a var to a file3. Users who are seeing strange results locally are already accustomed to going to help docs to see what version / flags Pages is running
column26: where they will find the answer simply enough.4. They could always e-mail support to fix their local build
column27: while the live site continues to build.## Things that would be good to have1. A command
column28: or a gist with a rake task
column29: etc. that would upgrade permalinks (I\'m imagining a site with 1000\'s of pages)2. A deprecation warning if I have on
column30: and a page in the folder
column31: has a permalink of  ## Other options discussed:1. Rip bandaid2. Switch in Jekyll core to opt-in3. Revert behavior in core
column32: sunset (somehow)4. Proactively warn users5. Upgrade script users would run locally + clear instructions Thoughts? //cc @mojombo

column10: b"b' :thumbsup:'"

b'b" Chatted with @parkr in #Jekyll ([transcript]url  Here\'s the current thinking:1. flag in set to through 1.12. Throw a warning at build time if they are using relative permalinks (permalinks in subfolders)3. New command to show which pages are using relative permalinks4. Work to educate and transition users to new permlainks over next few months This would **not break** any sites if we upgrade Pages
column11: can provide users a clear upgrade path
column12: and can early opt-in now
column13: and then eventually opt-out down the line."'

column10: b'b" Switching behavior on a minor release doesn\'t seem compatible with semantic versioning."'
b'b" We technically switched the behaviour in 1.0
column11: but we want a consistent experience on GitHub Pages. SemVer is a great guideline but I don\'t think I can break things like this when it\'s used heavily by non-developers and there\'s no way to see output. So we\'ll have to switch the default in 1.1 to OFF but for now
column12: we just print a very loud deprecation warning."'

column11: which slows down things. Maybe add to  ?'"

A few suggestions:[x] Output the path to the file it\'s currently processing ( **huge help in large sites** )[x] Don\'t display the backtrace unless I use the flag. Makes it really hard to see what actually matters[ ] ~~If one file fails

column10: b'b" :-1: on a logging level option. We should just decide the optimal logging level for the user. We started out trying to make things easier in this ticket
column11: lets not end by adding Yet Another Option and making things more complicated. Mostly I was talking about super vague errors like [the ones above]url  Any way to make these more for humans
column12: or is this a vendor thing? I believe some errors may output the file name
column13: but I swear most of the error I get don\'t. Will play around a bit and try to collect more specific errors to bring the discussion back to more concrete
column14: actionable items and we can go from there."'

column10: b'b" Hm
column11: why don\'t you like a verbose option? It would default to :info but if a user wanted to test a new plugin or something (or ship a plugin with build-in debugging info)
column12: then we\'d provide a nice way for users to do that. I really like verbose options for things like homebrew
column13: ssh
column14: gcc
column15: etc. For big sites (\\xc3\\xa0 la @mattgemmell\'s ridiculously large site)
column16: he could see Jekyll hard at work generating their site and working. It won\'t be the default
column17: but why not offer the option? To me
column18: it\'s as essential as  ."'

column10: b'b" Because Jekyll is all about Zen-like simplicity. That\'s what makes it so attractive. That\'s why people prefer it over things like WordPress or Drupal. Because there aren\'t 1000 options. Because the developers make sane decisions on my behalf
column11: and thus make the act of publishing worry-free by absorbing all the complexity of the scary world of computers and the internet for me. To get specific... there\'s the backtrace flag
column12: which plugin developers can use. What would be exposed in the different logging levels? I just don\'t want to see become a Christmas tree of options. Every option we add adds complexity for the user and increases the learning curve."'

column10: b'b\' Ok
column11: I retract the proposition to create a   option. I\\\'d still like to explore the idea of a flag. I\\\'m not trying to remove any of its simplicity (if ever has the complexity of
column12: shoot me) or tarnish its zen-like nature by adding a flag. I would argue that Homebrew possesses a zen-like simplicity much like Jekyll
column13: as it absorbs all the complexity involved in managing packages. When something does go wrong
column14: however
column15: I can retry with a option and see _exactly_ where it hangs
column16: stops
column17: or otherwise freaks out. I\\\'m not super attached to the idea of a option \\xe2\\x80\\x93 I just think it\\\'d be useful for debugging a problematic build of my site. Having heard many
column18: many folks write in our issues that they spend hours trying to debug a tiny issue
column19: I thought it would be good to give a bit more transparency. I haven\\\'t quite decided where I think it would be most useful
column20: but definitely at render time. That way if there\\\'s some unknown error before Jekyll can catch it
column21: you know which file was processing. This\\\'d be especially helpful for those pesky "ASCII not UTF-8" issues. It was just a consideration. Obviously we need to fix the error messages and mitigate some errors that should just be gracefully handled. This was an idea to give a bit more transparency to what Jekyll is doing. :)\''

column10: b'b" Jekyll is eating a particular paragraph only if it\'s the first paragraph."'
b'b" I use Jekyll for a little project where I retype 2 pages of Ulysses everyday url  hosted url  So far things couldn\'t be better. However
column11: on Day Seventeen
column12: I have encountered a strange bug that only seems to effect that single post. Jekyll (jekyll serve
column13: jekyll build
column14: github jekyll) does not render the first paragraph\\xe2\\x80\\x94 _at all_
column15: it doesn\'t exist in the site\'s code
column16: but it does exist in the markdown file. A little background. I use the same Rakefile to generate a new post everytime
column17: and I generated Day 17 several times to ensure there wasn\'t any user error. For the live version
column18: I\'ve gotten around it by inserting a tag in the first line
column19: and this gave me an idea: I placed a random paragraph before the paragraph in question
column20: and it rendered fine as the 2nd paragraph (all paragraphs accounted for). It\'s a very strange problem
column21: perhaps there is something in Joyce\'s writing that Jekyll doesn\'t like. This is the offending paragraph:What on earth is it about this paragraph that Jekyll doesn\'t like? "'

column10: b'b" Alright. So it\'s nothing as nefarious as Jekyll adopting a distaste for Joyce
column11: which would have been really interesting. The problem appears to be the colon in the first line. If I escape the colon
column12: everything works as it should. However
column13: this colon is squarely outside of the YAML header:so why is it causing trouble? "'

column10: b"b' Just guessing
column11: but does escaping / quoting the colons in the date solve the issue?'"

column10: b'b" @adregan You need to have a newline after your YAML: In your example above
column11: it doesn\'t look like it\'s formatted this way."'

column10: b'b" Yes escaping the colon does help
column11: and I have also added the extra line. So: I have just switched to RDiscount after reading [Issue 127]url  and [Issue 126]url  Apparently this is a problem with Maruku. It can\'t handle a colon on the first line. Problem solved. Go figure. So that leads me to a new question: Are there any unforeseen issues with using RDiscount? Why does Maruku happen to be the default of the Jekyll project?"'

column10: b"b' Here is the issue over on the [Maruku project]url  When they release 1.0 this feature will be off by default.'"
b'b" No unforeseen issues using RDiscount of which I am aware. RedCarpet is probably the best (and fastest) parser
column11: so if RDiscount gives you headaches
column12: try RedCarpet. MaRuKu isn\'t the default for any particular reason. It was chosen way back when and we haven\'t modified the default since then."'

column10: b'b" One of my live Jekyll sites on Github Pages recently ceased compiling due to what maruku deemed as a missing line-break between two sibling elements in a markdown file. The html was 100% valid
column11: flawless even :P but maruku complained about the  s not having a blank line between them. Ridiculous. Prior to Github Pages upgrading their Jekyll version
column12: eveything was fine.  If you\'re saying Maruku isn\'t actually that great
column13: and that redcarpet is so much better (I\'ve switched to redcarpet and not only is it faster
column14: but far less precious about that missing line break) wouldn\'t it be worth replacing the dependency on maruku
column15: with redcarpet in the gemspec?"'

column10: b'b" @davecranwell We\'re sunk into MaRuKu at this point. It\'s the default for thousands of users and if we switched all of a sudden
column11: there would be a lot of broken sites. Imagine that you have a site that you\'ve been editing with  on GitHub Pages. You don\'t test whether your site compiles on your local machine: it\'s just easier to make your edits on prose and push to GitHub and let GitHub do the heavy lifting. You\'re happily using the default
column12: as you have no tags and you haven\'t hit any of the other downsides of MaRuKu. Now imagine that we update Jekyll and GitHub Pages to use RedCarpet. Next time you go to edit your site and push to GitHub
column13: your site doesn\'t change like it normally did. You go make another edit to double-check that it\'s indeed not a problem with Prose. You see your updates on GitHub just like normal but your site still isn\'t building. You finally clone down your repo
column14: install Jekyll and run it yourself. You\'re now getting some esoteric error about some markup you have that used a MaRuKu feature that RedCarpet doesn\'t support and doesn\'t have a replacement for. The error
column15: of course
column16: is super cryptic and you don\'t recognize that you\'re using a new markdown parser because you just used the default. Why did it stop working all of a sudden? You go to Google and StackOverflow for answers but you can\'t find anything. You finally write a ticket on  in hopes that someone else knows what\'s up and a day later you get a response that the default changed from MaRuKu to RedCarpet and that you need to modify your file in order to get the old behaviour back. So now you\'re out a day\'s worth of work just because the dev team likes RedCarpet more than MaRuKu
column17: and you\'re frustrated as hell about it. Now multiply this times a couple thousand and you have yourself the scale of frustration that the change in default will cause. It seems like such a simple change
column18: but the ramifications are enormous."'

column10: b'b" TL;DR: Build software for everyday users
column11: not computer scientists. This was touched on a bit in #1113. If Jekyll were an internal software library (like Maruku or Rails or Sinatra)
column12: it wouldn\'t be a problem. You could assume the 80% use case was sophisticated developers who understand and respect the nuances of semantic versioning
column13: can debug breaking changes rather quickly
column14: and most importantly
column15: either vendor or version their software in a Gemfile. A breaking change is fine because I just won\'t update the Gem
column16: and besides
column17: my release cycle is quarterly
column18: so I\'ll just deal with it before the next release. But that\'s not Jekyll. Jekyll\'s my website. My release cycle is daily. Sometime hourly. I chose Jekyll over something heavyweight like WordPress or Drupal because I crave simplicity. I don\'t want to have to worry about what version of Maruku I\'m running
column19: or what my Markdown pre-processor is
column20: or if somebody updated a plugin on  that isn\'t compatable with my theme. I just want it to work. This is my website we\'re talking about
column21: not an open source software project I maintain on the side. This is true for both Jekyll I host on S3 and GitHub pages hosted users. A year ago
column22: if I ran and all of a sudden my site didn\'t build because a week ago I ran in a different folder (after all
column23: I\'m probably not using  ... why would I need something so complex if Jekyll\'s the only Ruby app I use -true story)
column24: I\'d be pretty confused. And it\'s not like  []\' for nil:NilClass (NoMethodError) _ jekyll new"'

column10: b'b" Keeping with our philosophy of not breaking functionality that\'s already there
column11: we cannot prepend the content with a newline
column12: as MaRuKu actually allows you to specify some metadata on your first line. If we were to prepend the content with a newline
column13: we would break this functionality for some folks who might be using it that\'s not something I\'m comfortable doing. Check this out for more details: url "'

column11: @parkr. 1. How many people  be bitten by a colon in first paragraph?2. How many people intentionally use this Maruku feature via Jekyll? Seems like an easy opportunity to add a config option for the newline
column12: and default it to on. If there actually are any people on group 2 above
column13: it will be straightforward to inform them to turn on the new option. However
column14: the amount of people losing their first paragraphs will drop to zero.'"

column10: b"b' Working with multiple sources'"
b'b" I\'d love for Jekyll to support multiple sources
column11: like so: As it stands now our repo\'s contents in Bootstrap are quite messy as documentation is mixed with other various repo contents and it\'s hard to discern the organization of files. The example above highlights what I\'d like to achieve: place our docs pages in a directory
column12: keep the compiled CSS and JS files we generate and track via Git in
column13: and then have Jekyll build from both those. The current solution to this would be a build script or manually copy-pasta
column14: but that sucks and puts the burden on others to solve. Given Jekyll already has the ability to specify contents to generate and exclude
column15: I don\'t think this is too far fetched. Symlinks would solve this easily
column16: but they aren\'t allowed in GitHub Pages. Perhaps there can be rules for GHP using Jekyll with select folders? Dunno the security risks there (perhaps @benbalter can weigh in). That failing
column17: is it possible to allow for specifying an array of sources? "'

column10: b'b" This is very interesting. I\'ve thought about it for the last couple days and I can\'t come up with any reason it shouldn\'t be an option. We allow one to specify multiple plugin directories
column11: why not do the same for sources? Additionally
column12: with #1389
column13: one can ensure there is no overlap in output. Collision is my primary concern. It\'d be awesome to hear @benbalter\'s and @mattr-\'s thoughts on this as well."'

column10: b'b" I see two distinct issues here: 1. Wanting to put Jekyll in a sub-folder within a larger project so that the project\'s directory structure is clear2. Wanting to allow Jekyll to read from two source folders ## Sub-foldering We want to encourage people to use Jekyll for project docs. That\'s the whole point. You can do the Bootstrap route and put the docs right in the folder
column11: or you can have a separate gh-pages branch
column12: which can cause all sorts of headaches. Not to mention
column13: I think there\'s something huge to be said about versioning docs along side code
column14: especially when you do tags / releases. You can put files any place you want (including a docs folder)
column15: and just use permalinks to move them to the proper place. The only limitation on this as far as I can tell is the folders (includes
column16: layouts
column17: etc.). What about some mechanism that allows Jekyll to look to and  ? Or maybe something that automatically sub-folders the site to as site root? ## Multiple source folders This is fine for core if it doesn\'t add too much complexity
column18: but can you think of another use case? (Note: would need to change command-line behavior as well). We currently override this on Pages for practical (and security) reasons. Not sure how we could support it
column19: unless it were a non-source config variable that specified sub-folders of the source (e.g
column20: or or something). ## Building @mdo would native build support for less
column21: etc. help your problem? (#1277) **Edit**: Thinking through this some more
column22: I think either a config (which would be relative to source)
column23: or
column24: even better
column25: in terms of sane defaults
column27: which would essentially set what would be to or both is the best route to versioning Jekyll sites along side code."'

column10: b'b" I had a long and thoughtful comment

column12: and I don\'t really like either. How can Pages handle multiple sources?"'

column12: page or draft) and path.## DONE[x] basic implementation[x] fix for Ruby 1.8.7[x] more robust cucumber features[x] more robust path matching[x] inline code documentation[x] documentation for [x] document precedence handling @mattr-

column10: b"b' Seems good so far. Want to see the final version of course. :smiley: '"
b'b" One major difference between this and #969 is how precedence is handled. In #969
column11: if two default layouts are encountered
column12: the one with the longer (i.e. more specific) path or
column13: if both paths are the same
column14: with a type specification (if the other doesn\'t have one) is preferred. Here
column15: it\'s simply top-to-bottom: the bottom-most has the highest precedence
column16: the topmost the lowest. Do you think that\'s OK / better / worse?"'

column10: b'b" This is the difference between getting code markup with pygments support via Markdown rendering vs. getting code markup with pygments support via Liquid rendering. The liquid version supports more options because we expose pygments to it directly.  Since we offer two different versions
column11: one that\'s easy
column12: and the other that\'s more powerful
column13: i\'m not inclined to change this behavior right now. Anybody else have any thoughts?"'

column10: b"b' Why not just use a Gemfile with version deps? Going the vagrant route seems heavy handed for a solution that most Ruby projects use already. '"
b'b" Sure
column11: that\'s what I do for my Pages projects. There is also [github-pages]url  However since is a program that you run on your compter and expect to work in a predictable way
column12: it makes more sense that its runtime is isolated from the rest of your development environment. My rule of thumb is that [I keep the tools that I use separate from the development environment]url  I use for my libraries and apps. E.g. I might want to use
column16: or a similar tool while in my app\'s directory
column17: but the fact that these programs are written in Ruby is just an implementation detail. They don\'t need to be run using the same version of Ruby that my app is using
column18: their gems don\'t need to be among the shared gems of my current Ruby installation
column19: and I certainly won\'t add them to the Gemfile."'

column10: b"b' I just feel that judicious use of Bundler (future rubygems really) is the way to go. For instance
column11: I always leverage binstubs on all my new projects
column12: Jekyll included. I really can not make a good technical case against vagrant other than I have not felt the pain point to use it. Note that I am not a shallow user either. So the question is what does vagrant solve that a Gemfile and basic directions do not and is said issue substantive enough to warrant it? Or even some other methodology
column13: ala the Heroku Toolbelt.'"

column10: b'b" @metaskills You bring up some good points
column11: but think about your perspective: you\'re an experienced Ruby developer who knows how to use and manage gems
column12: and you can decipher the errors with relative ease. I\'d say that your argument is flawless until you consider a user less experienced with Ruby programming tools (maybe you come from a Java or Python background). The learning curve for understanding Bundler isn\'t that high
column13: but I\'d love to be able to get Jekyll in the hands of a group of users that aren\'t as experienced or savvy in their use and understanding of Ruby and its tools."'

column10: b'b" @mattrJekyll has a very strict rendering process
column11: and some things (e.g. HTML Pipeline) need to be run before or after a particular piece of this render process. For example
column12: if I wanted to write a plugin that linkified all statements in a Markdown file (like our  )
column13: they couldn\'t do it without monkey-patching some horribleness in or something. This gives a publicly accessible API through which plugin writers may run some code before and after certain pieces of the rendering process."'

column10: b'b" @parkr
column11: I\'d vote for a mechanism that allows chaining multiple filters on the same content
column12: not simply more granular control of where a single converter can run in the pipeline. @mattr-
column13: Two use cases that I\'ve run into
column14: FWIW
column15: are if I want to add emoji or @mention support. Both should really be run after the markdown\'s been converted to HTML
column16: such that emoji or @mentions in or blocks can be properly ignored
column17: or if I want to make a manual @mention like  . Right now
column18: I\'d need to hack it in as a generator that modifies posts directly
column19: and use extremely complex regex. Another use case
column20: for example borrowing from WordPress
column21: is they have the filter
column22: which they dogfood internally. If I write in a post
column23: regardless of what other processors run
column24: I always get on the otherside. If I wanted to do that with today
column25: there\'s nothing in core designed to support that (which I\'d imagine we\'d want to encourage)."'

b"b' Permit YAML blocks to end with three dots'"
b"b' The YAML spec permits blocks to end with three dots (...) in addition tothree dashes (-): url  Someprograms that work with Jekyll (e.g.
column11: Pandoc) prefer the dots to dashes. Thiscommit permits the YAML metadata block to end with either dots or dashes. Itincludes tests.'"

column10: b'b" I\'ve given this some thought and I see no reason we should change because of Pandoc\'s preference. If I\'ve learned anything in the last year
column11: it\'s that giving users too many ways to do something causes confusion. Also
column12: the YAML spec gives me rage so I don\'t care much what they have to say considering omitting the last segment is also valid. :smile:  What\'s the use-case for this?"'

column10: b'b" At least one of the reasons for using a plain-text blogging engine is to filter the posts through Unix-lie tools. It seems to me that if the spec says that multiple end of document delimiters are permitted
column11: and if other tools in the same space are using those delimiters
column12: then Jekyll ought to support the full spec (even if you don\'t like the spec). Pandoc documents now use a YAML header for metadata
column13: just like Jekyll posts. The use case is for files that can be both Pandoc documents and Jekyll blog posts. Yes
column14: omitting the last segment is valid in a file that contains only YAML
column15: but it wouldn\'t be valid in a file (like a Jekyll blog post or Pandoc document) that contains other information
column16: so that part of the spec is beside the point."'

column10: b'b" @mscharley: The problem isn\'t the size here
column11: per se. The problem is that there\'s already a fallback and a base64 svg for each gradient. Which browser supports base64 svg and doesn\'t support gradients? Fact is that as it is the svg fallback isjust bloat; I tried with IE7
column12: which is the oldest browser I can try but I doubt anyone cares about it

column14: which is expected

column10: b'b" Ideally
column11: I\'d like some feedback as to which browser versions you care about for the website. With this PR
column12: really old versions should be supported consistently
column13: so it\'s easier to clean up the older vendor prefixes if you decide to officially not support them."'

column10: b"b' :+1: Thanks for the cleanup! Didn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t realise there was so much junk in there :laughing: IE9 does not support gradients
column11: but it does support SVG backgrounds
column12: which is why these exist. If IE9 isn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t important enough as an audience to worry about gradients
column13: then that\\xe2\\x80\\x99s totally fine and it should still look acceptable with just a flat BG
column14: but that\\xe2\\x80\\x99s a decision for @parkr. Personally
column15: I don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t think the extra file size is causing any significant issues with the site
column16: and it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s an unfortunate habit that as engineers we constantly feel compelled to (prematurely?) optimize at the expense of (albeit small) groups of users. This is a relatively small and low-traffic site in the grand scheme of things
column17: and the fact that it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s a static site means it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s already going to be pretty fast since there\\xe2\\x80\\x99s no server-side processing time. If the extra nice touch of giving IE9 users gradients costs a KB or two and therefore maybe a few milliseconds of extra load time
column18: then my vote would be that it\\xe2\\x80\\x99s worth keeping in.'"

column10: b'b" @cobyism: thanks for the feedback. Here is what you have at the moment on master. Fallback background color for the gradients which isn\'t used at all
column11: since the SVG image plays the fallback role. My suggestion was to just get rid of the SVG images
column12: and use the simple background colors for those who are so unfortunate to still use an ancient browser. This seems like a fair trade to me... Note
column13: that all this isn\'t a premature optimization. It\'s in fact a big step towards cleaner CSS code for the future ;) Everyone tends to add new stuff
column14: but only few people clean up the old stuff :D Now
column15: how about the vendor prefixes? With my PR all vendor prefixes are added
column16: but should we even care for Chrome 3 for example? Or Firefox 3 for that matter. If you can give me a list of the supported browsers I can make sure the rules are followed throughout the file consistently."'

column10: b"b' Yeah
column11: like I said it depends how big of a priority it is for the project. I wouldn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t call IE9 ancient though\\xe2\\x80\\x94even on sites with very forward-thinking audiences it sees pretty heavy usage
column12: often because of heavily locked down corporate IT environments. On GitHub for example
column13: we typically see about 20% of our IE traffic coming from IE9. This is a reasonably tiny sliver of our _overall_ usage though
column14: and our CSS bundle is already pretty large
column15: so we don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t bother with svg gradients. It all comes down to the requirements for the project in question.Absolutely\\xe2\\x80\\x94I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m really grateful for and happy with the changes you\\xe2\\x80\\x99ve made
column16: and I totally agree that cleaner code is going to make maintainability way easier for future contributors. My comment about premature optimization wasn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t a personal remark in any way
column17: it was really in regard to weighing up the SVG gradients against CSS file size\\xe2\\x80\\x94as far as I see it
column18: this isn\\xe2\\x80\\x99t a huge performance concern with the site at the moment
column19: so it felt premature to use it to justify removal of gradients for IE9 users. To summarize
column20: if the argument for removing gradients from the site for IE9 users is made on the basis that 1) the browser is ancient and 2) it\\xe2\\x80\\x99ll make noticeable difference to the site\\xe2\\x80\\x99s load time
column21: then I would dispute both those assertions. :heart: '"

column10: b'b" This is honestly a bit of an unfortunate mess
column11: which I haven\'t fully figured out yet. If you\'re using RVM
column12: it seems updating the psych gem affects the current Ruby
column13: which fixes the problem
column14: unless you\'re using Bundler
column15: in which case you also need to add to your Gemfile. If you have Ruby installed system-wide
column16: on the other hand
column17: I\'m not sure updating the psych gem accomplishes anything. I could be wrong about that. However
column18: if you\'re using Ubuntu
column19: updating the libyaml-0-2 package introduces a backported fix which SafeYAML won\'t detect (see #57). My understanding is that if you are using the latest version of RVM
column20: the new autolibs feature will compile Ruby with the libyaml fix for you (hence the fix that @boyanpenkov just mentioned). I could be wrong about that
column21: too. What I just wrote is basically the sum of my rough memory of little spats of troubleshooting I\'ve had time to put in here and there over the past couple days. It could be inaccurate in the details; but what I _am_ confident about is that there are unfortunate inconsistencies in how to resolve this issue between systems. This is something I obviously need to figure out and fix (by providing a more helpful warning message
column22: where appropriate) in the near future. The good news is that for now
column23: if you just want to get rid of the warning
column24: it\'s quite easy: require safe_yaml 1.0.1 instead of 1.0.2. The two should be functionally equivalent except for this warning."'

b"b' Setting Collections Relative Directory: Right Approach?'"

b'b\' This discussion is related to a [PR]url  I made to set a configuration variable for a Collection\\\'s location in the directory structure. I\\\'m putting it here in an issue to open a broader discussion
column11: if anyone cares
column12: about the best approach to this. Currently
column13: a Collection\\\'s "relative_directory" is set to the Collection label. The documentation is a bit confusing here
column14: because one can apparently access the relative_directory
column15: but not configure it. I believe it will be better for users
column16: including content creators
column17: to optionally organize their collections into a folder or folders. So
column18: is it best to be able to set each Collection\\\'s directory
column19: or set all Collections\\\' directory
column20: or set aside (thinking of a previous conversation on this) the _includes and _layouts folder so everything else is content? I\\\'ve been trying to shove most of my content into a _documents folder and with a bit of finagling (setting permalinks) I can get them to render where I\\\'d like. Ideally there\\\'d be a way to have a lot of control over the directory structure to keep it organized. Thoughts appreciated.\''

column10: b'b" This is a really thorny issue. I feel like the more we allow everything to be configurable
column11: the more we diverge from GitHub Pages and the more confusing life becomes for newcomers. This starts to feel like we\'re really working to separate all content from the  which is generally good
column12: but it feels like a :rabbit: hole that I just don\'t want to venture down quite yet. Thanks for the idea though!"'

column10: b"b' very well. maybe something for me to lobby for in the 3.0 discussion'"
b"b' Please do! :)'"
b'b" I think something like this should be considered for Jekyll 3.0. Separating the site code from the content is important. If we can\'t have proper themes (think @imathis\'s Octopress Ink)
column11: then we could offer something like this so at least content could be encapsulated into one folder. The last piece seems to be and collection paths \\xe2\\x80\\x93 they\'d have to be configurable the way everything else is."'

column11: as I\'m taking a stab at implementing a fix
column12: either as part of #3490 or a separate PR.  Rather than introduce any new config settings
column13: my intent is to just make the current behavior a little smarter with regard to URL endings for pages and collections based on the setting
column14: which is the confusion that @bcomnes initially described. So my intended behavior for page URLs is something like:if you have
column15: then use the current logic.  That is:  html index pages use  other html pages use  all other pages use  if you have or
column16: use the current logic for that
column17: which means all pages use  otherwise
column18: page URLs should match the ending style specified in  .  That is:  if ends with a trailing slash
column19: then use  if ends with
column20: then use  if uses extensionless URLs (neither trailing slash or  )
column21: then use  . HTML index pages will continue to just use
column22: and non-HTML pages will always use  . (**edit:** another way to say all that is that page URLs simply always match post URLs with regard to their ending style.  The extra logic is only there to handle the built-in permalink styles pretty
column23: none
column24: and date) Default permalinks for collections follow the same basic logic
column25: barring index pages and such where not applicable. It sounds like a lot of logic
column26: but it\'s really not too bad.  And honestly I think it\'s much more intuitive than the current behavior
column27: and still only needs the single config setting.  Please let me know if this sounds like a reasonable approach to you all."'

column10: b"b' Ok
column11: the documentation here has to be updated based on the link you shared. The script seems to deploy in somewhat of a round-about way. Why not: The script in the gem seems much more complicated with temp directories and such. Why go for such complexity?'"

column10: b'b" Well
column11: there are a few things I had to keep in mind:1.  /  are not available on Mac (at least by default)2. branch will be absent at the first run of the gem3. may not be installed4. we don\'t want to see repository URL in logs
column12: since it may contain user name and password (esp. when executed by travis-ci) I thought that it\'s better to use a temporary directory
column13: instead of a locally created one. I agree that the script is more complicated now than it should be. I\'ll try to simplify it now.. Thanks for the hints!"'

column10: b"b' @parkr please take a look again
column11: I removed some non-important noise: url  I still think that using /tmp is a better practice comparing to creating a directory in current dir (what if such a dir already exists? what if we fail in the middle of the script and this directory will confuse the user?) what do you think? Version 1.6.1 of the gem released to Rubygems: url '"

column10: b'b" While I appreciate the work that you\'ve put in to make deploying Jekyll sites with custom plugins to GitHub Pages easier
column11: I\'m :-1: on including a link to your gem in the documentation
column12: for the following reasons:1. Because we mention it in our documentation
column13: it\'ll be somehow seen as an official thing that we support
column14: which we have neither the time or people power to do.2. It\'s very specific to the UNIX environment. Our user base on the Windows platform is growing and I feel like
column15: where we can
column16: we should do our best to address both sides of the pond (so to speak).3. It\'s use-case is also specific
column17: to that of deploying a site via CI. While this is excellent automation to have
column18: I don\'t feel it\'s generic enough
column19: or at least the documentation in your README isn\'t generic enough for using it for anything other than CI
column20: since that\'s the only use case you document. In short
column21: I think you\'ve created a wonderful tool for yourself and others with your specific goals and use cases
column22: but not something we can market (for lack of a better word) to the wider Jekyll community."'

column10: b"b' Proposal: multiple formats per page using layouts'"
b'b" As far as I can tell
column11: it\'s not possible to have two output formats for a single  at the moment. We have a case where we\'d like to generate an iCal file for each post
column12: as well as the HTML version. It seems to me that a nice way to do this would be to allow multiple extensions for each layout
column13: and generate a file for each extension in the specified layout. For instance
column14: if we had a post
column15: and two layouts
column16: and
column17: you would end up with output in both and  . I\'ll have a go at this when I find time
column18: but I was wondering if anyone could highlight any fundamental reasons why this wouldn\'t work
column19: or problems that might be encountered when writing it?"'

column10: b'b" Makes sense. @parkr any strong opinion on this? To me it\'s in line with Jekyll\'s do what I ask
column11: no more
column12: no less philosophy
column13: and does exactly what you\'d expect. "'

column10: b'b" Only strong opinion is that it\'s backwards-compatible. A layout like will have to ask for
column11: whereas a layout like will have to ask for  . We\'ll have to do a to see if it\'s there and ensure security is tight around this check
column12: but other than that this is doable. It\'d have to be in the key for this to work and we\'ll have to mostly rewrite the way we render to keep track of a _list_ rather than a _string_. It redefines what we call a
column13: or as a one-input-many-outputs (where many is >= 1) document. The 1-1 relationship could no longer be assumed but would still have to be supported. They\'ll just be 2 files sitting side-by-side with different file extensions. Is that what you\'re looking for? In general I\'m :+1:
column14: but it\'s going to be a pretty heavy lift. Any help would be greatly appreciated."'

b'b" Hey @Floppy
column11: been thinking about this a lot and we should implement this for v3.2 or v3.3. If you have time
column12: I was thinking we\'d go this route:1. Each  would define the output formats it wants **in addition to the one assigned by its source filename** (e.g. for  ). Front matter defaults would also apply
column13: so doing this for a larger number of files would be trivial.2. Those formats would use the same layout as for the HTML page
column14: but with the new ending
column15: e.g. when in the document.3. The layout would define the behaviour. Whether you want JSON
column16: CSV
column17: XML
column18: or some other output
column19: the layout would be in charge of manipulating the data into the desired output.4. They would have identical permalinks with the exception of the extension. In the case of permalinks
column20: it would be accessible at for consistency.5. Accessing this link in Liquid would be
column22: etc. The extension would be stripped of all non-alphanumerical characters and would be used as a prefix for  . **If you comment
column23: please do not simply write :+1:.  If you do
column24: your comment will be removed as it produces unnecessary notifications for others. Please react with a :+1: emoji instead
column25: or offer a critique of the above points. Thanks!**"'

column10: b"b' This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least two months. The resources of the Jekyll team are limited
column11: and so we are asking for your help. If this is a **bug** and you can still reproduce this error on the 3.3-stable or master branch
column12: please reply with all of the information you have about it in order to keep the issue open. If this is a **feature request**
column13: please consider building it first as a plugin. Jekyll 3 introduced [hooks]url  which provide convenient access points throughout the Jekyll build pipeline whereby most needs can be fulfilled. If this is something that cannot be built as a plugin
column14: then please provide more information about why in order to keep this issue open. This issue will automatically be closed in two months if no further activity occurs. Thank you for all your contributions.'"

column10: b'b" Just chiming in that multiple output formats seems an obvious missing feature which I\'d love to use
column11: particularly around making site data more easily consumable by other systems. Currently thinking about how I can plugin this
column12: presumably as a Generator
column13: but would love this built in.  Functionality I\'d be after:  * syntax to me seems simplest \\xe2\\x80\\x93 we simply extend from being able to define 1 to being able to define many * Layouts are extension agnostic: could be
column15: \\xe2\\x80\\x93 doesn\'t matter. They are referred to by their extensionless filename (as per existing functionality). Up to the developer to avoid name clashes. * These could in turn be nested inside other
column16: multiple layouts. That is
column17: could specify:  . These again are agnostic e.g.
column18: * The final file at the end takes the extension of the highest-level layout. * In cases of filename clash
column19: layouts defined later append the layout name to the filename
column20: e.g. page_ (whereas the first defined layout would be e.g. )  Why this way?  1. No reason to limit this to the use case of multiple unique formats. What about multiple different outputs in the same format? 2. Nesting makes sense. E.g. you might build up a JavaScript fragment by nesting JS layouts
column21: which is then ultimately pumped into an HTML layout\'s head. That is
column22: formats often contain other formats
column23: but the biggest container defines the overall format."'

column10: b'b" What we need is a graph of dependencies so that we can just rebuild this graph. Unfortunately
column11: support for this doesn\'t exist. @jaybe-jekyll worked out something the other day whereby he was able to regenerate only the files which where changed. Right now jekyll-watch doesn\'t pass any info about what\'s changed to Jekyll
column12: but it could potentially do that. Then we have to do a selective read (which isn\'t supported)
column13: and to ask the to be kind to things not re-generated. Or just not re-read every damn file every time we run (currently we start from a new state every time
column14: i.e. 0 posts
column15: 0 pages
column16: 0 documents
column17: etc)"'

column10: b"b' Incremental regeneration'"

b'b" Almost complete implementation of incremental regeneration (#380 and #3060)  between as well as within a process. Currently handles file content changes and dependency changes (layouts and includes only). This implementation takes a few things from @mattr-\'s implementation in #1761. Here is what happens on each build:1. The class is initialized and reads in metadata from (metadata is not read if the flag is set).2. Jekyll performs
column12: and as it did before.3. In the render step
column13: all documents
column14: pages
column15: and posts are checked for modifications to itself or its dependencies. A  is also marked as modified if it has in its front-matter.4. is performed if the flag is set.5. Modified files
column16: as well as the new
column17: are written in  . Remarks:Although initial (no metadata present) build times went up a tiny bit
column18: builds with metadata are super quick ([here]url  are the results from the [ site]url Dependencies in the form of referencing  in Liquid with are not resolved. (This is why I included the front-matter override.) Any ideas on how we can make this work?The metadata file is currently YAML (loaded with SafeYAML). Is this optimal
column19: or would another serialization method work better? Todo:[x] Implement behaviour[x] Fix failing tests[x] Add tests (cucumber & unit)[x] Add more unit tests!"'

column10: b"b' Allow collections YAML to end with dots'"

b'b" Posts can have YAML front matter that ends with three dots instead of dashes since 52ac2b3 but that only applies to posts. This PR adds the ability for the YAML front matter of collections files to end with dots as well. I don\'t have very much experience in writing ruby code and tests
column11: but I managed to write one. It probably can be improved but I just don\'t have enough experience to know how to do that yet."'

column10: b'b\' Hm. As much as I want to abide by the YAML spec
column11: I want to make it such that each outcome has only one method to achieve it. So saying "either dots or dashes" does not help new users learn Jekyll... it just complicates things. I agree we should have parity but I guess I\\\'d rather we use dashes everywhere.\''

column10: b'b" It seems like
column11: either way
column12: a firm decision should be made. Dots are ok everywhere
column13: or dots are ok nowhere. I don\'t know what Jekyll would have to gain by breaking compatibility with the YAML spec; that doesn\'t make things easier."'

column10: b"b' It gains simplicity
column11: directness. I agree we need a decision. I will think on it.'"

column14: since that now relies on returning the correct extension.  Since the new [jekyll-textile-converter]url  plugin isn\\\'t present when running tests

column10: b'b" At this point
column11: those tests are more regression tests \\xe2\\x80\\x93 ensuring we don\'t mistakenly break support for Textile. Think that\'s not a good idea?  Thanks for the issue
column12: Will :)"'

column10: b'b" but since the tests are running without the textile plugin
column11: I\'m not sure that it\'s _actually_ testing for regression of textile support.  I guess it may be testing to make sure that non-markdown in general are supported reasonably well?  Though that is certainly not all the tests I\'m looking at... I know at least some of them are testing functionality that could just as easily be tested with markdown files. I think we should definitely keep some regression tests around that ensure we support non-markdown files
column12: but since textile has been moved out of core
column13: I\'m not sure that it\'s necessary to have regressions for that specifically.  Or if we do
column14: we should actually load the textile plugin as part of tests (which I think would be fine)?"'

column11: you\'re right. They aren\'t running with the plugin installed... How very strange. I guess it\'s not really testing anything then. :hankey: :cocktail:  We pretty much know the converter stuff works."'

column10: b'b" segfaults are usually because you\'re loading a library compiled for a different ruby version. try uninstalling those gems and re-installing them. looks like posix-spawn / ."'
b"b' Also :metal: for linguistics!'"

b'b" Yep I haven\'t switched out of 2.0.0-p643 since I started compiling them\\xe2\\x80\\x94all gems are compiled with the same version of ruby that\'s running them. I even tried re-installing ruby in case that was the problem rather than just the gems."'
b'b" Can we have you cross-file this on url  since it\'s their library that is segfaulting and if you don\'t mind
column11: can you please tell me the version you have of posix-spawn you have so I can (or somebody else with a Macbook) can test it and see if they can get it to segfault.  It would be nice if you provide the complete steps to your build process to both us and them so that we can both try and replicate it. It\'s true that segfaults can be caused (sometimes) by using the wrong Ruby version but most of the time it\'s caused by a library not handling something inside of the code properly and even if posix-spawn does not support Ruby 2.0.0 (I\'m not saying if it does or doesn\'t) a segfault should not happen."'

b'b" Addressing [this issue]url  #2518  **Aim:** allow the directory that a collection is in to be different to  . **Reason:** e.g. for cleanliness of the top-level directory we could have and list all of our collections under there. **Achieved by:** allow the user to set the property of a collection in with the path to the collection\'s directory. For example: **Example:** Suppose I had a collection  . Before this patch
column11: it would have to be in  . Suppose now I move it to  . In
column12: just add to  \'s metadata: The resulting collection:has label (**regardless** of the name of the actual directory name
column13: in this case though in practice you\'d keep the name of the directory the same as the name of the collection).is copied to  each document in the collection has property
column14: rather than  . This is the only thing I might think of as being inconsistent. **Questions** Are the tests rigorous enough? And what about behaviour re: the last point? Note in the \'master\' version of jekyll this property would be the absolute path to the (source) file
column15: e.g.  . In this PR it changes to the relative path  . The jekyll documentation says should be According to this
column16: the property should really be (being relative to the collection directory)
column17: so both the current jekyll and this PR jekyll are getting it wrong the former gives an _absolute_ path
column18: and the later gives a relative path
column19: but to the site\'s directory (not the collection\'s directory). But perhaps that should be a separate issue (whereby either the docs are updated or the meaning of is made clear)
column20: particularly as changing would probably break many people\'s sites."'

b'b" I\'ve been experimenting with Markdown files as page sources in a Jekyll site
column11: and it seems to work fine apart from code blocks if the file has ..it\'s appearing in the site page as My code example (ie with code tags)
column12: rather than the expected My code example (with pre tags
column13: which is how it\'s rendered in the Github UI). It means that
column14: for example
column15: all line breaks in code snippets are lost (making them in some cases unreadable)
column16: and any nice code box pre formatting in the CSS isn\'t used. Obviously I can get around it by just replacing the backticks with pre tags but it would be nice to be able to copy in existing pure Markdown files without having to add inline HTML."'

column10: b"b' This sounds like a quirk of your Markdown processor rather than a Jekyll issue.'"

b'b" If you do something like this \\xe2\\x80\\xa6 \\xe2\\x80\\xa6 make sure to always add two newlines between code blocks and paragraphs. Same goes for headings. Also notice that I used as a replacement for the backticks so it looks like a perfectly fine code example. Now if you already do that it would help to know which Markdown processor you\'re currently using. The default for Jekyll (i.e. you didn\'t set one yourself in the _) is kramdown."'

b'b" Is there any reason to be able to override the ID? I\'m just wondering since there is a lack of explanation as to why you would want to do such a thing on either ticket."'
b'b" Ah
column11: sorry. In a feed
column12: a post\'s should never ever change
column13: even if permalink does. If a publish a post
column14: and later change it\'s URL
column15: I can redirect the old URL to the new one
column16: and I should also be able to keep the existing ID
column17: rather than being forced to take a new one. Likewise
column18: if I import posts from another blog to my Jekyll site
column19: I should be able to keep whatever ID the old blogging engine gave a post
column20: rather than risk giving all my posts new IDs. The way a feed reader knows which posts are unread is by keeping track of read IDs. If the ID of a read post changes
column21: the feed reader will think that it is a new unread post and display it again. The GitHub blog
column22: for instance
column23: uses a form of ID that looks nothing at all like a permalink
column24: ie:  "'

column10: b'b" That\'s good to know

column11: @pathawks
column12: and I\'m not sure it\'s something I\'d like to allow. What requires that this be overridable? Just imported posts?"'

column10: b'b" It\'s because the  shouldn\'t change even if the title changes that way feed readers know it\'s not a new article.  Say I update a post title a month after I publish it
column11: feedly would assume right now that it\'s a new post because the  changed
column12: this shouldn\'t happen and is bad caching behavior.  We are basically the ones who are breaking the expected behavior of Atom."'

column10: b'b\' This functionality is necessary to generate true "permalinks" as in [cool URIs don\\\'t change]url  Many websites have adopted a URL structure with alpha-numeric IDs to allow them to scale. [Read my thoughts]url A related issue (which doesn\\\'t necessarily prevent implementation) is the fact Jekyll uses the permalink structure to produce the directory structure and file names. To appropriately implement an evergreen permalink structure using IDs
column11: you must use server-level redirection. Jekyll aims to work "out of the box"
column12: and while more robust
column13: a solid permalink structure requires additional configuration. I would love to see Jekyll decouple the permalink structure from the folder structure to allow advanced configuration options.\''

column10: b"b' Permalinks can be specified per-post already. This is an unrelated issue.'"
b'b" @pathawks The issue confuses me.. You want to **be able to alter a post\'s id** so that **the *id* does not change** when you change your post\'s permalink..?"'
b'b\' The post ID should not be a "dated permalink" (as it is today). It should be an alpha numeric ID (ideally fixed length) which does not change ever. Dates can change
column11: post titles can change
column12: but the post ID should be immutable.\''

column10: b"b' @ashmaroli I am not the one who reopened this issue. I have found other solutions.'"
b'b" This is a static site generator
column11: if you wanted static post-id\'s you should have picked a database driven solution that indexes.  This is approaching interfacing the database as an API level over-concerning here."'

jekyll	3735	closed	3	goodtouch	2015-05-25 18:17:18	3.97		+1		b'b" Hi @parkr! I\'ve been quite busy lately, sorry for the delay \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x85 . Yeah I\'ve seen the before working on this one, but if I remember well it doesn\'t support multiple properties order (ie.  ), or nested properties (ie. as in #3539). The first implementation I made wasn\'t using code generation, but as @envygeeks was concerned about performance, I tested some different ways to do it, benchmarked them and went with the parsing + generated one since it was much faster (you can see #3720 for the discussion and [-bench]url  for the benchmarks). I added some safety guards ([validation Regexp]url  and a customizable [limit]url  of generated sort methods) to prevent evaluation of arbitrary code and high  consumption. I can add more safety checks or fallback to any non code-generating version if you prefer, it\'s really up to you (and maybe the average number of items to sort in collections hosted on GitHub Pages).Using a method to access the hash like [this one]url  works, is safe, but is also much slower. Whatever configuration format you prefer is also fine by me as long as it supports multiple and nested sorting (all of them are safe and simple to parse, it\'s really the method that matters). Using and or  ,  ,  , or doesn\'t make much of a difference to me and should be quite easy to change once decided (naming is always the hardest part \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x81  )."'

Let\'s decide what the best default is and if it\'s absolutely crucial to have a backwards-compatibility option like this one (for example

column10: b'b" It\'s not the web servers that will complain because they are by default case-sensitive and I believe it\'s only Apache that can be configured to break that defacto rule. If I\'m honest I\'m gonna vote for anything that follows the (not official) golden rule that pretty much everybody follows: everything in the URL should be lowercase.  So when it comes to writing tags and categories I will always vote for normalizing them like slugs and enforcing a lowercase."'
b'b" Where do you see this golden rule? I wasn\'t aware of it. Is it default for all webservers?"'

b'b" @parkr It\'s **_unofficial**_ and I consider it golden because it\'s used all over the place and probably because of the way Google and Yahoo will treat inconsistent URL\'s with different content."'

column15: just lowercase everything in the URL for consistency (there are obvious exceptions to this rule -but IMO tags is not one of them) but it\'s easier to just lowercase it all and normalize a slug so it\'s easy to read

column10: b"b' #### Summary The installation problem occurs because OS X ships with a copy of Ruby in
column11: a directory which is owned and controlled by the OS. In past versions of OS X
column12: a new jekyll user could use to install software into this directory. That may not be possible in OS X 10.11
column13: because Apple is now using System Integrity Protection (SIP) to further restrict write access to some system directories. @fulldecent found a good work-around for 10.11: A drawback with this work-around is that the user needs to install Homebrew and Ruby before installing jekyll. The user may also need to update their $PATH variable to give precedence over  .'"

column10: b"b' It would be helpful to re-open this issue to give it more visibility.'"
b"b' I just tried the work-around described above and it worked flawlessly.'"
b"b' @chmaynard Thanks for your help. Is your system a stock upgrade or install? And have you installed Xcode command line tools before doing this? I just want to track all the factors here.'"
b"b' @fulldecent I previously installed both Xcode and Homebrew. We probably need to refine your install procedure for people who are not developers. See below.'"

b"b' #### Proposed Checklist for Mac OS X 10.11 El Capitan[ ] Install the Xcode command line utilities  [ ] Install Homebrew (instructions at url [ ] Modify $PATH to use Homebrew  [ ] Modify $PATH for GUI apps  [ ] Install the latest Ruby  [ ] Install the latest Jekyll Note: Homebrew is designed to work without using sudo.'"

column10: b'b\' @yratof did you add a timezone to your posts? The latest version of jekyll 3 has fixed all the problems for me as long as there\\\'s a "+0100" next to the date in my post file.\''
b"b' That worked \\xe2\\x80\\x93 Fantastic. This should be something that could be documented for future upgraders Cheers @marco'"
b'b\' We were struggling with a similar issue. Tracked the problem down to the safe_yaml gem: url  What this appears to do is to read dates in UTC
column11: then convert them to the local time zone. We are +1
column12: so what happens is that every date that gets parsed by safe_yaml has 1 hour added to it. That means that they are "in the future" and jekyll doesn\\\'t want to render them. We\\\'re adding \\\'\\\' to all our dates in order to get correct times on our posts. Might be prudent to get this patched upstream or to not allow safe_yaml to parse these dates. As far as I can tell
column13: the way jekylls does this in behaves correctly (at least in all the timezones I tested it in).\''

column10: b'b" I\'ve been using this to created posts with the time + 0100 added to the endof the generation url  On 6 November 2015 at 12:58
column11: Robin K\\xc3\\xa5veland Hansen <notifications@"'
thanks for sharing!'"

column10: b'b" What\'s the status on this? This is still around and quite annoying to track down. Things behave exactly as described by @kaaveland on my end."'

b'b" @kleinfreund Unfortunately I\'m not sure what to do here. A first step would be to use UNIX timestamps instead of instances everywhere. If we can use UNIX for UTC then it\'s much easier to compare and timezones become merely a presentation detail."'
b'b" The workaround of putting the timezone with the timestamp is fine for now
column11: but probably should be documented somewhere to help people who encounter this issue in the future. The other options would be to file an issue with safe_yaml that this behaviour should be changed (which I would suspect they\'d be reluctant to do seeing as there\'s probably plenty of software that relies on this behaviour at this point) or toggled off somehow. The path of least resistance would probably be to make everything timezone-aware or to calculate the result from safe_yaml back into utc or unix timestamps. Feels like it would be easy to get this wrong either way
column12: with the dst-minefield and everything here. I\'m seeing people add etc to their timestamps (which is a timezone without dst)
column13: going to guess some people will run into problems with that sort of approach further down the line as well. Going to sign off with this one: url "'

column10: b'b" Not to be offensive but if you don\'t write your times with a zone you\'re doing time wrong anyways.  How are we supposed to guess what time zone you are in if reading your source? Reading it on Github
column11: reading it anywhere."'

column10: b'b\' Fair enough
column11: but the actual issue (at least the one we observed) comes up as "I wrote down the current time and jekyll doesn\\\'t show my blog post" or some variation of that. I can\\\'t quite recall how I ended up in this rabbithole to begin with. Maybe the unreliability of a timestamp without a timezone should be documented somewhere very visible or maybe it should produce a warning? I\\\'m sorry if this is already the case
column12: I didn\\\'t see it at the time this was relevant for me. For what it\\\'s worth
column13: I completely agree that guessing at timezones isn\\\'t really viable. Currently though
column14: safe_yaml does that for you (it picks the users local timezone). That means that if I send my source without a timezone in my timestamp to a collaborator in India
column15: he won\\\'t be able to render it for 3 hours and a half unless he changes the timestamp. \''

column10: b'b" This is a long standing issue with Ruby itself which never truly handled Time correctly anyways and seems to go out of it\'s way to mess it up or make it hard every release at one point Jekylll did go out of it\'s way to try and help alleviate that but it was fragile anyways
column11: over the years it\'s gotten easier kind-of but it\'s still broken.  Take a look at Rails; they literally goes out of their way to make this easy by shimming the crap out of
column12: and (which that list in-and-of itself should tell you how bad time is in Ruby.) The problem here if I remember right (I haven\'t re-read anything again in this ticket) is that we do not infer the timezone I\'d have to go back over it
column13: but ultimately let me say this
column14: there are plans in my personal backlog to one day solve problems with time in Jekyll
column15: it\'s just not an important issue because the lot of us include a TimeZone anyways."'

column10: b"b' Setting the variable in _ can be a solution. With no set : A date with no offset is considered to be GMT (+0000). If you build your site at
column11: your post is in the future and not published
column12: except if you set in config or use  . If you set the timezone (eg: offset +0100 )
column13: any post whith no offset is considered to be +0100. If you build your site at 2015-12-26 00:00:01 +0100
column14: your post is in the past and published.'"

column10: b"b' Consolidate caches and create a _cache folder for *all* to use.'"
b'b\' Today we did an audit for our biggest Jekyll site and noticed it has like 8 cache folders
column11: this is pretty big and unwieldy
column12: it also makes it harder for us to control the caching on our build servers.  We should create a folder and consolidate all Jekyll caching into that folder
column13: and then ask plugin authors to place their caches in that folder too with or without prefixes.  Exp:  Now cleanup went from "let me figure out what is what" to  \''

column10: b"b' /cc @'"
b'b" Let\'s add the removal of these caches to the command."'
b'b" :+1: Good idea! It\'d be easier for users in terms of ignoring these files for source control as well."'
b'b" Are any sites using for content? That\'s what worries me here."'
b'b" @parkr make it configurable then
column11: out of all the configuration options that a system should have
column12: where it caches is a high-priority unless it uses system caches
column13: and especially if it uses local directory caching.  We allow it on Jekyll-Assets which gives users flexibility on where they place their cache and how
column14: it\'s not a bad idea for Jekyll and I don\'t know the YACO applies here because for people like me who build hundreds of sites putting our caches in a global directory and controlling them gives us much more flexibility in our build systems
column15: how we build all that
column16: and it gives the average user more flexibility in how dirty their folder is at the root."'
