column10: b"b' WIP: Incremental regen improvements'"
b'b" Done my exams! :sweat_smile: The main change here is the addition of a tag
column11: which is equivalent to using something like
column12: except it plays better with incremental regeneration. Basically
column13: when used
column14: it adds the referenced  as a dependency in the regen metadata
column15: and manually renders the  if it\'s not already rendered. This is still very much a work in progress (except for the first commit
column16: which is just additional tests). **_Definite shortcoming**_: I don\'t think this handles the case of adding posts; we\'ll probably need a whole separate system for that. A couple of questions
column17: too:Should this be a filter
column18: not a tag?Would Liquid Drops make it possible to put this in accesses to directly instead? (@envygeeks?)"'

column10: b"b' Usage would be the same as the current uses for  : Here
column11: with incremental regen on
column12: if a post is modified
column13: the page with the above code would be regenerated as well.'"

column10: b'b" I\'m a bit resistant on a hefty logic change like this in 3.x because we already ask a lot of users to move to 3.x
column11: now we are asking even more in 3.1 or 3.2 but my resistance will be ended if we do move to drops because that will solve the core of this problem without asking anything of the user other than to upgrade."'

column10: b"b' Moving to drops will break the merge_payload hook unless we convert to hash then create a new drop from that hash. '"
b'b\' @parkr nothing stops us from adding basic hash methods onto Drop and passing that drop instance as the "hash" since we would need to store a basic internal hash of static stuff anyways.\''
b'b" Changing the payload to Drop can allow us inject code into accessor ( we did this while using DotLiquid )
column11: and this is the cleanest way for users
column12: they don\'t need to make any content change. I vote for this one instead of creating another . "'

column10: b'b" @envygeeks The rationale I have for this right now is that:1. Incremental regeneration is disabled by default
column11: but this improves the experience for users who have it enabled2. No existing functionality is broken; this won\'t affect any existing site in any way (unless they happen to have specified in their frontmatter
column12: which is quite minor anyway). So
column13: as far as I can tell
column14: this is a Pareto improvement in  theory terms (at least one person is better off and nobody is worse off). That said
column15: if using Drops will make things easier
column16: I would vote for going that route as well. We\'ll see once we get at least basic Drop functionality working. I\'m definitely not going to merge this until then."'

column10: b'b" _Re. the tests_: This seems kind of on the border to me. I\'m fine either way. Putting the tests in unit allows us to be a bit more specific about things (for example
column11: checking to see if the dependency was added explicitly)
column12: but putting it as a feature test might be a bit more idiomatic..."'

column10: b'b" Ha! You have most certainly just emerged from the depths of finals. Hope they went well! :smiley:  Let\'s go the Drop route. I\'ll write up something over Christmas and see if I can come up with an acceptable solution. I will add the usual and methods as well for easy accessing of non-method keys. Anything else you\'d recommend?"'
b'b" Sounds good! There\'s not much else... Maybe moving pages to Renderer if that\'s possible?"'
b"b' That would be excellent!'"
b'b" @alfredxing what\'s the status of this?"'
b'b" I haven\'t have time yet to look into this again since Drops. I\'ll see if I can take advantage of anything there."'
b'b" @parkr I moved all the logic into DocumentDrop
column11: reflecting our shift to Drops. Everything is a lot simpler! Using Drops has the benefit of a lot more context—the Drop knows what document is being requested
column12: in addition to having access to the Liquid context (thus also knowing what  is requesting it). However
column13: I haven\'t touched any of the Page stuff yet (so usages of won\'t add a dependency yet). Do we want to move pages into a collection as well
column14: or was that plan dropped (no pun intended!)? I\'m mostly in favour of it since it would likely simplify the rendering process by quite a bit. I was thinking in order to achieve this logically
column15: we can make a new class that contains all of the defaults needed to make everything compatible and output to the right place... anyway
column16: this is probably for another discussion :wink: Back on the Regenerator front

b"b' Refactor Errors'"
b'b" @envygeeks has pointed this out to me privately before
column11: and I think he\'s right: our errors could use some improvement. Right now
column12: we throw generic or incomplete errors. For
column13: we don\'t even give the user the option to get the stacktrace (#3773). There are often duplications in the output
column14: too
column15: which is confusing. Goals:Simplify error handling codeGive developer consumers a much easier way to differentiate errorsReduce user confusion I think we should do the following:[ ] Settle on or for everything[ ] Identify possible spots in the code that cause errors and identify discrete custom error classes they could create[ ] Create custom errors for each error case
column16: such as
column18: and that handle errors throughout the build process[ ] Allow each error to provide context (e.g.  )[ ] Allow each error to provide help info (e.g. for more info"'

column10: b'b" That\'s what we do in all our projects (as a crude example):   That way throughout our entire stack we can rescue just and let any other case bubble as either a bug or a user problem because it wasn\'t a case that we chose to cover.  So we only care about exceptions we create or re-create."'
b"b' @envygeeks that sounds like a typo in frontmatter or markdown processing may kill instead of displaying the error and keep listening to file changes.'"
b'b" @TWiStErRob No
column11: those errors should be rescued and raised with our own classes and covered.  The errors that should not be rescued are plugin errors that randomly happen
column12: we should just throw and let everything fall down
column13: unexpected errors in our own source that we didn\'t cover which should surface bugs better and otherwise. Liquid Errors
column14: Markdown Errors
column15: YAML errors should all be rescued and thrown as our own Error and rescued higher up the chain to spit out a clean message or in some circumstances to throw the entire instance if we deem it necessary."'

column10: b'b" Hmm
column11: that sounds reasonable
column12: but I still think you shouldn\'t die as soon as something goes wrong
column13: even if it\'s a plugin
column14: as you can\'t distinguish between:an exception thrown by a plugin that was caused by a user input which is recoverable within instance by editing a file (sans restart)an exception thrown by a plugin that was caused by a bug in the plugin and it left the plugin in an inconsistent state Of course the best course of action would be to interface with plugins in a defined manner
column15: e.g. by saying that if plugin throws a type of it\'s handled by Jekyll
column16: anything else will fail really fast. Sorry if all this is already done
column17: just want you to understand my point. Having to restart often would be really annoying."'

column10: b'b" If a plugin wishes to do that they subclass Jekyll::Error::StandardError and it will automatically be covered since the surface of the entire app only handles and outputs a clean error message without letting it throw the instance if it\'s a Jekyll::Error::StandardError.  Nothing stops plugin authors from doing that
column11: and from my perspective
column12: if they are handling their own errors that would be ideal for them to do if they know what they are doing. Other than that the latter case you listed are exact reasons why we need to let it fall down. An inconsistent state can cause dismay everywhere
column13: we have no idea what is going on therefore we should not try to figure it out
column14: lest we create a bigger problem."'

column10: b"b' The power of the entire system lies in Jekyll::ErrorStandardError
column11: all our errors subclass that error
column12: and we only rescue that error on the surface of the app
column13: we literally and output the message that it gives us as the error and continue on (with a backtrace if the user asks for it.)  All errors we throw are sub-classes of StandardError
column14: so we only need to rescue once to cover all our cases... and again it would be ideal if Plugin authors used our StandardError to encapsulate their recoverable errors too.'"

column10: b"b' Let me correct this: Should not try to let it continue... lest we create a bigger problem.  We should try to figure it out
column11: but letting it go on could cause bigger problems.'"

column10: b"b' Agreed
column11: thanks for the clarifications
column12: you guys are awesome!'"

column11: with full backwards compatibility? The idea being

column13: gems" isn\\\'t a very intuitive term (even though that\\\'s what they are). Further, users shouldn\\\'t have to care about (or see) the behind-the-scenes plumbing, in terms of how things are distributed. Instead, let\\\'s call the key "plugins

column10: b'b" No. It\'s not stale."'
b"b' Gem-based themes'"
b'b" Similar to what we did with Gem-based plugins
column11: we should introduce the concept of Gem-based themes
column12: making it easier for users to style their content
column13: and hopefully creating a more robust theme ecosystem.### How themes work today Today
column14: while there are lots of great Jekyll themes out there
column15: the installation process generally involves either forking a repo or copying files into the destination site. The problem with this approach
column16: beyond ease of use and the ability to quickly switch themes
column17: is that there\'s no good way to downstream subsequent updates (not to mention
column18: from a DRY perspective
column19: the theme\'s CSS and templates now exist in hundreds or thousands of repos
column20: each with their own versions and edits).### How Gem-based themes would work for users Find a theme you like? Simply add in your site\'s file. That\'ll instruct Jekyll to load the Gem-based theme
column21: just like it would any plugin. The theme would be able to register layouts
column22: and its static assets (css
column23: javascript
column24: images
column25: etc.) would be automatically included in the built site. Heck
column28: to include the theme\'s assets in your HTML. Lets say the theme has a layout. If you don\'t like it
column29: simply create a layout in your standard folder with the same name. At render time Jekyll will first look to the user\'s layouts and includes
column31: it\'ll then look to the theme\'s. As an added bonus
column32: if you\'re just using the theme defaults
column33: we\'ve allowed you to better separate content from presentation
column34: as your repo is now almost entirely your own content
column35: with less Jekyll noise getting in your way.### How Gem-based themes would work for theme creators Themes are just Gems with a defined folder structure
column36: not unlike the Jekyll site itself. The only required file would be the Gemspec itself. Beyond that
column37: you can introduce as many layouts you\'d like
column40: the folder can automatically be included in sass\'s include path (meaning the user could just do to include your css in there own). We can also define some sort of ( ?) folder
column41: which\'ll be automatically included as a whole
column43: maybe themes can even be dependencies of other themes (e.g.
column44: a vanilla Bootstrap theme might be a dependency of Hyde). We\'ll probably also want to include a screenshot in a predictable path.### A note on security From a GitHub Pages perspective
column45: it\'d be important to us that themes not be allowed to contain any server-side executable code (e.g.
column46: only liquid-based logic). As far as I understand it
column47: the Gemspec isn\'t executed once the Gem is built. That would allow us to very quickly whitelist a large number of themes for use with GitHub Pages (and would then not have to strictly version each)
column48: allowing theme developers to push updates to Rubygems
column49: which would then update the version used by GitHub Pages
column50: without requiring (much) human intervention. If themes need advanced functionality
column51: they can require a plugin (which could go through the existing review process).### A note on conventions Right now
column52: everyone has their own design patterns. Is it or  ? or  ? or  ? For themes to be truly fungible
column53: we\'ll probably want to put out some sort of style guide for themes
column55: and how best to implement them in cross-theme ways.### A note on our own theme If we went down this path
column56: the default Jekyll theme (that\'s bundled with Jekyll)
column57: would be pulled out into its own Gem. could them simply create the necessary config and folder structure. Heck
column58: maybe could even take a theme name and be capable to generate a boilerplate site for any theme. Thoughts? I Know there\'s some prior art within Octopress
column59: but think making themes first class citizens of the Jekyll world
column61: could go a long way to level up the Jekyll publishing experience

column10: b'b" Ok
column11: after talking for a while with @benbalter
column12: I\'m happy with the decision to move forward with Gem-based themes _only_. The advantages to gem-based themes are significant:1. Less prone to errors when sharing either your site or your theme ( \\xf0\\x9f\\x8c\\x9f \\xf0\\x9f\\x8c\\x9f \\xf0\\x9f\\x8c\\x9f \\xf0\\x9f\\x8c\\x9f \\xf0\\x9f\\x8c\\x9f )2. We will ship a command
column14: which makes the creation of the files and directories a one-step process. It will include instructions as well as a scaffold.3. Private
column15: ad-hoc themes are still supported through  (private repo) or local (  in Gemfile) distribution.4. A little added overhead for the theme creator makes it _much_ simpler for users. Versioning (including
column16: crucially
column17: the ability to roll back to a previous version) is paramount here. This decision took me a couple weeks of thought which is much longer than I usually take for these sorts of things. I read all the comments above and talked it out at length with Ben
column18: arguing that it should be configurable. Ultimately
column19: he convinced me that the need for a wonderful user experience for the consumer of a theme (not the producer) over many months and years is what is important. Cloning a repository to some random location on your machine and pointing your config there is not a sustainable way to solve the problem of shared layouts
column20: includes
column21: and styles. As an implementation detail
column22: we will have to setup load paths for layouts & includes anyway
column23: so a plugin could easily inject more paths if it so chose. With that

column10: b'b" Building sites with absolute URLs is fine if you are not using  . What if we added a new config variable called (or an alternative) that parsed the html after build to alter the paths from working in the base directory to working in the new base path. This would leave relative paths alone and update absolute ones to contain the base path. The output directory would have all of the files built into a folder of the same name as the base path allowing no configuration to the server. This would remove all of the confusion of using baseurl as it would simply work. Looking at the HTML output it would make sense to someone who understands HTML. As an additional plus
column11: there would be no need to use liquid on paths anymore with {{  | prefix:  }}. Not sold on the idea
column12: just thought I\'d put it down. "'

column12: we need the end user to be on the version that Github pages uses (which will soon be 3.1 -granted it\'s 3.0 but read on) or for others 3.1 right now.  Slightly outdated doesn\'t cut it here
column13: we get dozens of tickets a day.  This means that given a few months Debian will be outdated and so will Ubuntu because Github has already announced the move to 3.1 within the next few months (actually I think it\'s either this month or next?) Adding Debian\'s outdated packages and supporting their slow cycles complicates matters
column14: and because it\'s an LTS we\'ll constantly get tickets and asked to fix bugs on a version that by the time it updates we will probably be on 4.0.  Debian doesn\'t issue bug fixes

column10: b'b" I am generally \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8e on these kinds of changes. This feels like a filesystem issue to me. I have never used hardlinks on Mac or Linux before so I don\'t know how they\'d behave using various filesystems. "'
b'b\' I\\\'m not sure I understand your statement or your opposition. Currently
column11: Jekyll is copying each static file. With large files
column12: this is slow.  With the patch
column13: enabling hardlinks causes Jekyll to link the files instead. This is significantly faster as it essentially only has to create a directory entry and increment a link count. As for OS or file system support
column14: every modern OS supports link. Certainly Windows supports it and it\\\'s part of [POSIX]url  As for file system support
column15: it\\\'s supported on EXT2/3/4
column16: JFS
column17: ReiserFS
column18: btrfs
column19: FFS
column20: UFS
column21: XFS
column22: HFS+
column23: ZFS
column24: and NTFS (among
column25: I\\\'m sure
column26: many others). The file systems that I know don\\\'t support it FAT12/16/32
column28: and Plan 9. I don\\\'t understand what you mean about not knowing how they behave on various file systems? "The function shall atomically create a new link for the existing file and the link count of the file shall be incremented by one."  Do you mean the subtle point in the POSIX specification about how it behaves when linking to a symlink being implementation dependent? If so
column29: that seems easy to canonicalize the behavior by calling on the source first. Maybe I\\\'m misunderstood your point. As a single data point
column30: building the small site I\\\'m working on that contains about 4 GB of static files takes about 11 seconds without hard links and about 1.3 seconds with. This is a pretty big win

column10: b"b' I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m pretty \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8e\\xf0\\x9f\\x8f\\xbc on this idea conceptually. I think this should be handled by copy-on-write at the file system level (like APFS). I\\xe2\\x80\\x99m not sure that copying static files is going to be the bottleneck for typical sites.'"
b'b" @ashmaroli Ideally
column11: hard links would be made for files on the same file system and files would be copied for files on different file systems. As it\'s currently implemented
column12: it doesn\'t check for that and hard links would simply not work in the scenario where the destination of the copy is not the same file system as the source.  @pathawks then I think the PR should just be closed since it seems like Jekyll developers are opposed. I admit
column13: I don\'t really understand the opposition. Being able to create hard links is a pretty massive speed up for my site which has 5 files that together are more than 7 GB. (They are VM images for my students.)  I also don\'t really understand the contention that this should be handled by the file system itself. Many file systems support hard links but most don\'t handle the sort of deduping necessary to make this process fast.  Incremental builds aren\'t really an option either since they don\'t properly track changes in data files (or correctly handle generated content in some cases). I spent a little time trying to wrap an external dependency tracking around an incremental Jekyll build
column14: but it was error-prone  I agree that this is unlikely to be a bottleneck for most sites (and I believe the default was to have hard links disabled). But it\'s a pretty minimal change with nice performance benefits."'

column10: b'b" I\'m totally fine adding hardlinks support. There are some very clear benefits. What remains unclear is when to use them instead of copying:  1. Opt-in using a CLI option or option in the configuration? 2. Always use soft links in 3. Always use hard links in as long as the source and destination are on the same disk (requires some intimate knowledge of the system
column11: but theoretically doable \\xe2\\x80\\x93 does the system throw an error when making a hard link to a file that doesn\'t exist?)  This indecision \\xe2\\x98\\x9d\\xef\\xb8\\x8f is what is causing hesitation in my opinion. I think hard links are a wonderful idea
column12: but there are some complications. \\xf0\\x9f\\x90\\x89 "'

column10: b'b" WTB the aforementioned Option 1. I\'ve got a few large static files managed in jekyll websites and not only is there the generation cost
column11: but also the on-disk waste of space. You could even make it more granular -I\'d be happy even with the ability to specify which files should be hard-linked on a per-file basis. I expect that would solve @stevecheckoway\'s issue as well since he has a few large files that are the majority of the problem. That might also help some of the concern about complexity. If it allows the user to opt-in specifically where they need it
column12: presumably it would only be done for large files. Heck
column13: call the option  . That should prevent any confusion with gem theme overrides. "'

column10: b"b' Make Jekyll hyper-parallel
column11: how about we make Jekyll fast
column12: yes?'"

column10: b'b" This commit introduces parallel processing into Jekyll
column11: which in essence will speed up builds for people with larges sites... considerably. By throwing out many forked Jekyll\'s to process each piece independently marshaling and bringing back in pieces of data as necessary Jekyll can get exponential (possibly) increases of processing power with better IO and more cores.  How much will this speed up Jekyll? That is url  and it was built on my personal 24 core server.  Jekyll consumed little over 10 of my cores and built the site in 2 seconds compared to the 36 seconds it normally takes to build that site.  On Jekyll\'s own site
column12: the build time goes from 9 seconds average to 3-4 seconds on my 4 core Skylake on Linux. **_This pull request still needs work
column13: however
column14: it works for most sites as it stands
column15: we hav tested it across a dozen or so sites
column16: however there are some stuff that still needs to be accounted for.**_ This feature was paid for and sponsored by @forestryio (@jpatters and @scottgallant) who wanted it for  and to also hand it back over to the open-source community so it could benefit the entire world and not just them."'

column10: b'b" @benbalter I thought we could use lazy evaluation but @envygeeks knows more about this than me so I\'ll happily go along with his implementation :)"'
b'b" @benbalter @spudowiar The data is processed outside of the main process where shared memory does not happen.  We get a copy of the memory with our own bits if we choose to edit something
column11: but those changes **_do not**_ land back in the main process
column12: we must marshal and ship the data back
column13: well technically upstream marshals it and ships it back
column14: we do have a marshal and unmarshal method but those are relics for testing what needed to be there when development to see what needed to be excluded from the marshal because it was too complex (read: hashes with default procs or anything with a proc that we cared about.) There are two ways we can do things:
column15: or Marshal.  I will not be implementing ... ever.  It\'s too slow
column16: and it will make this pull request meaningless
column17: Marshal is and remains the fastest way to marshal data from a sub-process back into the main process."'

column10: b"b' The Future of Theme Gems [Discussion]'"

b"b' The future of theme gems as I see it..:**Requires Jekyll 4.0**## Self-Contained Modules Theme gems will be self-contained _insta-jekyll_-modules. All they need would be **content**. This allows users to freely switch between themes without breaking their site or losing their customizations. For this to happen a few things will be prescribed and expected to be followed. A theme-gem ecosystem would be:SCAFFOLD DIRECTORIES [  ]every theme gem shall contain a **configuration file** named the same as the gem-name e.g. and it will reside inside  core styles and settings will be defined in and referenced in templates with liquid using the namespace. e.g.  the layout names will be standard for all theme-gems:  for index  for posts  for pages  as the parent layout for above layouts When overriding defaults
column11: the user creates the required file / copies from the gem_dir. into a directory named the same as the theme gem in use.  e.g.  etc  Jekyll 4.0 shall look for these directories first in the and then in the gem. Following this _convention_ ensures easy switching between theme gems at the same time preserving their customizations.'"

column10: b"b' Happy New Year @jekyllbot !! :laughing: '"
b'b\' I agree with some folks here that supporting a directory would be really
column11: really useful. For one
column12: it would allow people to publish sites to GitHub Pages (and other Jekyll-based platforms) without being constrained to whitelisted themes
column13: and remove the burden of having to "unbundle" themes using the [awkward process]url  described in the Jekyll docs.  Here are some use cases to consider:  * A user wants to use a theme that isn\\\'t supported by GitHub Pages. * A user wants to contribute changes to a theme
column14: but doesn\\\'t know how to test it locally because they aren\\\'t familiar with Ruby  Gems
column15: which makes testing locally difficult or impossible. * A user wants the ability to easily switch between themes
column16: or even build a site multiple times with different themes.  In all of these cases
column17: support for a directory has the potential to make the user\\\'s life easier. They can try a theme out by copying it to and updating their Jekyll config
column18: rather than monkeying with Bundler. They can publish their theme to GitHub without having to know how to publish a Gem. Theme users can install and keep the theme up-to-date with git submodules. And users can remove the theme later by removing a single directory
column19: rather than having to hunt down all of its files individually (which is what people must do now when they follow [these instructions]url The documentation itself alludes to "regular themes"
column20: which aren\\\'t really a thing without support for the directory. I think the single-directory format would be a lot easier for some users to work with and allow folks to experiment more easily and with less risk of ending up in a bad state.\''

column11: @shawnbot. In addition to removing a theme being easier in a directory
column12: updating it will be as well. Another advantage is the ability have [WordPress-style "child themes"]url  that inherit the basic styles and templates from a parent but allow a user to build and override them as needed. #5343 has some discussion of this
column13: too. Managing the templates of regular and "child" themes would be tremendously easier in a directory for template designers who aren\\\'t familiar with Ruby and Gems.\''

column10: b"b' So then instead of have two different places to look for a
column11: there would be three. \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x95'"

column10: b'b"  If backwards compatibility is not on the cards for   then templates need not reside at the root but should rather be housed within   **theme-gem < overrides in  ** reduce fragmentation by enforcing a limited scope:   all themes to have a common name-set for layouts:     if that\'s too extreme
column11: layouts shouldn\'t be hard-coded within documents. Use Front Matter Defaults.   other (remaining) layouts to be converted into  . penalize inclusion of within markdown or content documents. All of that should be handled by layouts / includes.  With the above
column12: trying out various themes become less stressful."'

column10: b'b" @pathawks gem-based themes can already inherit from one another in sneaky ways
column11: e.g. by including other themes\' Sass files. At the very least
column12: I think directory-based themes
column13: whether they inherit from other themes or not
column14: would be easier to debug because you can search (with
column16: etc.) the filesystem for similarly named files or contents. This is a lot harder to do with gem-based themes because the gem files typically live outside the working directory."'

column10: b'b" I didn\'t think we had any concept of child themes yet.  It seems like including a theme in the working directory defeats the entire purpose of having a theme. Perhaps we should add more documentation explaining that a theme does not have to be published to RubyGems
column11: or even exist on a remote server at all; Gems can already just be a directory."'

b'b" Ease of installation
column11: yes: Gemify a theme and use it on more than one projects by the same author Just have the Gemfile reference the theme..  But
column12: we\'re discussing about switching  various themes
column13: previewing them

column10: b'b\' Sorry if I wasn\\\'t clear: I meant that it\\\'s possible to do sneaky things within a Gem that allow you to informally "inherit" from another Gem-based theme; not that theme inheritance is a supported feature
column11: nor that it should be.  I also agree that Gem-based themes are much easier to install for people who are familiar with Gems and Ruby. However
column12: they\\\'re not usable on GitHub Pages unless they\\\'re on GitHub\\\'s very short whitelist. And for people who are less familiar with Ruby but know their way around the filesystem enough to put a simple Jekyll site together
column13: I think that directory-based themes would be a huge boon.  Some context: I work for the U.S. government and am on the [Web Design Standards]url  team. We\\\'re looking at creating a Jekyll theme for the Standards that people with little to no git or GitHub (let alone Ruby or Gem) experience can use and deploy on GitHub Pages and other Jekyll-based platforms
column14: such as [Federalist]url  Federalist builds Jekyll sites in containerized environments and doesn\\\'t restrict Gems
column15: so we can scaffold new sites with a Gem-based theme there. But some agencies and departments can and do publish directly to GitHub Pages
column16: which means that we need to provide additional tooling to "unbundle" a Gem-based Standards theme and apply updates to the theme. If directory-based themes were a thing
column17: then we could scaffold those sites with set up as a git submodule that points to the theme repo
column18: and every hosting environment would be able to handle it. Directory-based themes are also easier for users to run locally because they don\\\'t necessarily involve having to use Bundler at all: clone the repo with (or use the GitHub desktop app)
column19: and if you have Jekyll installed globally you can just run in the project directory. \\xf0\\x9f\\x92\\xa5 In short: directory-based themes offer a simpler mechanism for distribution that\\\'s compatible with hosting environments that don\\\'t allow arbitrary Gems
column20: and are potentially much easier for users to run locally.\''

column10: b'b" This discussion seems to have strayed far from my original intent.  @shawnbot
column11: According to you
column12: the chief necessity of directory-based themes is to be able to host on GitHub Pages using git submodules that\'ll will cater to people who have little to no prior experience with Git or GitHub Pages. Confusing..  But the common ground for everyone in favor of a directory is that Jekyll no longer looks for the — at the root of the site\'s but rather in  :+1: "'

column10: b'b\' Yeah
column11: I\\\'m sorry if I hijacked the thread. I just wanted to +1000 the suggestion proposed by others before me
column12: and provide some more specific use cases.  I think the core concept of scaffold directories makes sense
column13: and I assume that the Gem-based theme implementation already provides some way to prepend resolution paths for different types of files (includes
column14: layouts
column15: Sass partials). If I knew Ruby well enough I\\\'d dive right in and see if I could hack together a solution
column16: but I humbly defer to the maintainers and Jekyll hackers on whether this is an easily implemented feature.  Here\\\'s how I would expect it to work
column17: assuming in the Jekyll config:  1. Attempt to require the gem  . If that succeeds
column18: add its "scaffold directories" to the appropriate resolution paths
column19: and perform any other Gem-based theme initialization necessary. 1. Otherwise
column20: check for the existence of in the source dir. If that exists
column21: add all of its scaffold directories to the resolution paths instead. 1. If the directory doesn\\\'t exist
column22: throw an error.  From there on out
column23: everything _should_ just work the same way
column24: right?\''

column10: b"b' @ashmaroli @vossad01 +1 for different files with varying themes. FWIW
column11: we have a niche use case for this: we use Jekyll to produce books as websites
column12: ebooks and in print. One Jekyll site might include several different books. At the moment
column13: if we use themes
column14: all books in a site must look roughly the same (i.e. they are based on the same theme). If different files could use different themes
column15: one Jekyll site could contain any number of very different books. '"

column10: b'b\' @arthurattwell Interesting use case
column11: The way I see it
column12: since the books are part of the same site
column13: there is at least some common ground where everything converge to
column14: and therefore the themes themselves must have a common ancestor.  The best solution hence is to develop an in-house theme to cater to this niche scenario and implement it via Front Matter Defaults:  each book is a collection item with entries as chapters:
column15: delegate these "books" with a of their own:     these individual layouts descend from the parent layout say  this allows scalability and write new layouts / use existing ones for new books \''

column10: b'b"  Sorry I thought I responded to this previously.  What I recalled originally triggered this was GitHub Pages.  At least some of those themes are only really built for a single page.  When a project wants to grow beyond that (ex. add documentation pages) it may be perfectly willing to accept a different theme for the new (documentation) pages to to  spending the time working on themes or being forced to change the appearance of its current page.  The other case that I thought of because of projects I have worked near
column11: but was not actually attempted is similar to @arthurattwell\'s.  The case of a project where its main website and its documentation website were developed separately
column12: and ended up with different themes. As they have grown
column13: it has become clear there would be efficiencies in merging the two.  The ability to have each keep their own theme reduces the barrier for merging them and lets the work of refactoring to a common theme be able to more easily happen over time."'

column10: b'b" I ran into the same error message
column11: and found this issue while trying to figure out the problem.  I am noting how I caused the problem and my solution for posterity
column12: in the event others find this issue as well.  I installed Jekyll for the first time following the [quickstart guide]url  I then followed the instructions to [convert a gem-based theme into a regular theme]url  In the process
column13: I deleted the directory found at  .  I created a second project following the [quickstart guide]url  again
column14: and when I invoked was greeted by the same error described above.   Thanks to the links from @pathawks
column15: I realized that the error being swallowed was a missing filepath minima had not been reinstalled during the second quickstart guide. I expected the second install to check and install dependencies
column16: but that is clearly not what happened.   Confusingly
column17: running did not fix the problem (I am unfamiliar with the Ruby ecosystem). Instead
column18: I used the following command.   It seems as though the following is also a viable solution.   I\'m afraid that I disagree with @DirtyF I believe this is a problem for Jekyll. The package purposefully [catches several types of errors]url  and rather than reporting what type of error it is
column19: returns a cryptic error about  . Having Jekyll return an error message about a specific missing path or package would have saved me an hour of work.  I hope others find this useful!"'

column11: that is some dodgy code.  This is a bug in Jekyll
column12: in one way or another
column13: regardless of what other people say.  In one case some part of the source is just going wild without nil checking
column14: in another part
column15: a method is rescuing a critical error causing the first bit of code to error
column16: while swallowing the error.  If that error swallowing is indeed necessary
column17: because the monster can\'t be sated it should:  1. Report the error via a debug message. 2. The other part that just goes wild based on an assumption should nil check 3. ; or it should throw out a non-critical warning
column18: to the user."'

b"b' The reason this is happening is because Jekyll [extracts the excerpt]url  from the raw post
column11: rather than the rendered post. When the excerpt separator is
column12: it will grab everything from the beginning of the post to the blank line
column13: which in this case happens to be right in the middle of our highlighted code block. This means that is inside the excerpt
column14: but is not.  A good solution is not immediately obvious to me
column15: aside from just returning a blank excerpt if there was any sort of error when rendering the excerpt.'"

b'b" I see two solutions (though there may be more):  ## 1. Test the excerpt to see if it compiles  If it does not compile
column11: grab the next text section up to the next empty line.  In C# pseudocode (I\'m not familiar with Ruby):   ## 2. Use Liquid\'s parser to decide where to stop the excerpt  This is much more complex."'

column10: b"b' Another possible solution:  ## 3. Stop the excerpt at the first Liquid tag encountered  The excerpt would not include the Liquid tag at all. This is probably the most reliable solution. Works as long as users can accept that limitation.'"

column14: so the file is displayed as:    ## See Also Related information:  * url  * url  * url  * url  * Issue #1312  ## Additional Details Using YAML as a bridge between documentation and applications is a slick way to avoid duplication. Since the YAML file is machine-readable

Using is insufficient here because of namespace clashes. There are a couple of options:  * Jekyll can read all the Markdown files alongside and pass them through a pre-processor; or * can specify the pre-processor file(s) to use against all

column11: but it requires a different namespace:   This would mean changing to  ; such a prefix wouldn\'t necessarily make sense in other contexts (external to Jekyll)
column12: and would require a lot of effort to refactor variable names across many Markdown documents (and verify that the refactor was performed correctly).  Also
column13: part of the problem is that the variables must be able to reference other variables
column14: with a variable interpolator to extract the correct dereferenced value (see
column15: above).  The collection attributes almost fits the bill
column16: but has the stringent requirement of not being a standalone YAML file (i.e.
column17: must be part of Markdown front matter).  Another issue is that it should be possible to define the variable delimiters
column18: such as:  * -and  ; * -and  ; or *   -   ."'

column10: b"b' It sounds the issue is more regarding the fundamentals of how Liquid works: what you are asking for is to define your own template language.'"
b'b"  Nothing so complex
column11: just two related ideas. First
column12: variable substitution for arbitrary definitions using a dot-separated notation and recursive interpolation. Second
column13: the ability to set a prefix and suffix delimiter used for finding and replacing variables with a [resolved value map]url I\'ve developed both of these in Java. The first is about [19 lines of code]url  The second requires a kind of [variable decorator pattern]url  which is also fairly trivial in terms of LoC (fewer than 50 lines).  Code that deals with variable substitution can hard-code variable delimiters in multiple places
column14: which is a violation of DRY. Using a constants is better practice
column15: but still violates DRY when those constants are referenced in multiple places
column16: rather than being constructed dynamically using a factory pattern based on some arbitrary criteria (such as a file name extension)."'

b"b' Specify order of collection items and set  links accordingly'"

b'b" [X] This is a feature request.   I want to be able to specify the order of items in a collection and have  links respect that.  **Use Case**  I am using Jekyll to build a lesson that contains several topics. Each topic is a separate Markdown file in the collection. Topics must be listed on the home page in a particular order
column11: and we want topics to have  links set correctly.  **What Doesn\'t Work**  We currently enforce ordering using a naming convention: topics are called
column14: etc. This works
column15: but when we want to re-order topics
column16: we need to rename many files whose content often hasn\'t changed
column17: which makes the version control log difficult to interpret.  We have tried using a list in to specify order:   and then using that loop and to create the ordered list in the home page:   However
column18: his doesn\'t help with  links within the topics. The only solution I\'ve been able to come up with for that is to use a search loop inside each topic to find it within the list
column19: but that means that building the site is O(N**2)
column20: since the search loop over N topics is run once for each topic
column21: and that makes builds noticeably slower for large lessons with 20-30 topics.  **What Might Work**  1.  Support an key in the metadata for each collection whose value is the ordered list of IDs of collection members. Values in the list that don\'t correspond to collection members are errors; collection members that are not listed are either an error or omitted.  2.  Set and links in the for each collection item to respect this ordering. "'

column11: that\'s what I do in the individual pages right now when building
column12: but it leads to O(N**2) runtime: each of N pages has to search an N-item list to find itself.  Or am I misunderstanding?"'

column11: I was misunderstanding. You are correct :+1:'"

b"b' Feature: Frontmatter Support in Includes'"

b'b\' I\\\'m working with jekyll themes at the moment btw. thanks for this long waited feature and coming around with an feature request to **support frontmatter header in include files**.  **Why?** When composing themes
column11: includes are typically used for functional blocks (for example a contact form or image gallery) which could be used on every page. These blocks have some preconfigured settings (in this example text
column12: form fields
column13: or images to include) for this include. For a better readability of the template those settings (or parameters) should be included and preconfigured in the header. When somebody wants to overwrite the include file he should copy the file and change the header.  I know that siteand pageparams exists
column14: but sometimes they are not enough for writing functional parts of a template.  Example implementation:  _  (use default setting)  {% include  %}  would Result: Hello world.  index2.html (overwrite by param)  {% include  headline="Hello USA!" %}  would Result: Hello USA!  What do you think of this request? I\\\'m the only one who thinks this is useful? Please give me some feedback if it makes sense to invest time in it to build this functionality (maybe for jekyll-master?)!\''

column10: b"b' [WIP] Add shim that works for both Rouge 1 and Rouge 2'"

b'b" This PR aims to allow Rouge v1 or v2 to be used with Jekyll. This will allow users to choose to stay on the old version or to upgrade if  want to. In url  we learned from @jneen that we cannot rely on the same classes if folks want to upgrade to Rouge 2. I have attempted to create a helper utility which creates the necessary Rouge formatter that we need to process our files. While this is still a work in progress
column11: I would appreciate any general opinions on the API design. I think I may have misinterpreted @jneen\'s comments in url  /cc url "'

b'b" Hey \\xf0\\x9f\\x91\\x8b  the main issue i encountered when working on #5230 was that it didn\'t seem possible to rebuilt the *exact* same output we had when using Rouge 1.7 and i was also not sure we even **want** to have the same exact output
column11: that\'s why i couldn\'t continue url In my opinion it would be best to have the input of some users who actually want to use the new features of Rouge 2 with Jekyll and then decide on a custom formatter (based on a provided formatter from Rouge v2 as @jneen suggested).  @parkr Still happy to help if you need any form of support on implementing this"'

column10: b'b"  Thanks! So it sounds like all people want from Rouge v2 are the extra formatters \\xe2\\x80\\x93 the Ruby API doesn\'t really matter. The reason we can\'t upgrade is that some people have written their _own_ formatters so we can\'t block them from using Rouge 1.  I wonder: if they\'re writing their own formatters or monkey-patching Jekyll to modify how it uses Rouge
column11: then maybe we can get away with allowing Rouge 1 & 2 in the gemspec
column12: upgrading to Rouge 2 in our code?  @envygeeks I seem to remember you mentioning that you\'d done some customization with Rouge. Can you help us understand what changes we can make to allow Rouge 2 that wouldn\'t affect you? If you\'re monkey-patching
column13: for example
column14: then we could just change the methods you have money-patched and be totally in the clear as long as our gemspec allows either version."'

Support for Rouge 2 [has been added]url  but [is yet to be released]url  Example:   Produces in  Rouge 1.11 with the current kramdown release 1.13.2: Produces in Rouge 2.10 with the current kramdown release 1.13.2 (as noted by DirtyF): Produces in Rouge 2.10 with the unreleased kramdown version (current master): The last code block adds an additional compared to Rouge 1.11 but it will look the same as in the old Rouge version.  To try it out locally (with jekyll docs): The [kramdown repo]url  has to be cloned. The version on github can\'t be used directly in the Gemfile as it doesn\'t include a  . After cloning run: Now reference the local version in Jekyll\'s Gemfile and run Remove from
column11: otherwise the site will not built. (still investigating why) Serve the docs  I could submit a failing PR for this behavior but not sure it\'ll be worth it as it\'ll only pass once a new kramdown version has been released."'

[x] I am on (or have tested on) ******   ### Due diligence: It is [well documented that your documents in a collection cannot be  ]url I have looked but have not found discussion on this decision.  The closest I have found is url ### Requested functionality: I would like the ability to treat files as documents so that I don\'t need to change the file extension and wrap the contents in front matter delimiters
column11: both of which create inconveniences.  I imagine this would need to take the form of a configuration setting in underneath the collection configuration.  ### Workaround:  In searching for existing issues about this
column12: I did find url  which informed me I can terminate my front-matter with (the yaml end of document delimiter) instead of  .  This makes it valid single-document YAML (a number of tools don\'t support multiple document).  ~~Then I can change the extension to and tell my editor to treat files as yaml~~  They YAML file is then seen as having front matter and is processed by Jekyll as desired (contrary to the documentation).  /cc @  "'

b"b' Jekyll messes up the kramdown hash
column11: creating symbols and string.'"

column10: b"b' Blame: url ![screenshot-2017-11-14_13-43-00]url  '"
b"b' Why is this important?'"
b"b' To further clarify
column11: I understand that the duplication of keys and values is not ideal. Is that the only reason for this particular issue?'"

column10: b'b" LOL
column11: I\'m out."'

column10: b"b' Seems legit
column11: if the duplication is here for no reason and we can avoid
column12: we will fix this.  /cc @  '"

column10: b'b" This was introduced in #6247 to fix #5980. In short
column11: kramdown wants option keys to be symbols
column12: but we get them from YAML as strings.  After we have merged the config hash with our defaults hash
column13: we go through and symbolize all the string keys.  url This results in items that have been added with a string key being duplicated.  I don\'t see any advantage in performing deduplication after this step
column14: but perhaps I am missing something.  We might be able to use symbols instead of keys for our defaults:  url Then we would need to call on the overrides before merging
column15: I guess. The downside here is that none of our other defaults seem to use symbol keys
column16: so that might be confusing.  Is the motivation here purely theoretical
column17: or is there something real to be gained? @DirtyF?"'

column10: b'b" If Kramdown wants option keys
column11: I don\'t see why we don\'t set Kramdown defaults as option keys from the start. I don\'t know about the gain
column12: maybe do plugins developers need to parse the kramdown options?"'

column10: b'b" @DirtyF The problem is merging in YAML
column11: since those will all have string keys. Also
column12: taking a look at [the defaults]url  everything else has a string key. If I didn\'t know anything about this issue
column13: and saw that some options were strings and some options were symbols
column14: I would be confused.  We can\'t be sure that plugin developers _don\'t_ rely on the current behavior of accessing via string keys rather than symbols
column15: so any change would have to bump the major version number I suppose."'

column10: b"b' Can we not symbolize these keys just before being passed onto Kramdown instead of storing them as symbols?'"
b"b' We do symbolize them just before passing them to kramdown; we just don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t remove the string keys.'"
b"b' I meant something like.. '"
b"b' @ashmaroli I don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t understand what that accomplishes
column11: but then I really don\\xe2\\x80\\x99t fully understand the problem here anyway
column12: so I defer.'"

b"b' This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least two months. The resources of the Jekyll team are limited
column11: and so we are asking for your help. If this is a **bug** and you can still reproduce this error on the 3.3-stable or master branch
column12: please reply with all of the information you have about it in order to keep the issue open. If this is a **feature request**
column13: please consider building it first as a plugin. Jekyll 3 introduced [hooks]url  which provide convenient access points throughout the Jekyll build pipeline whereby most needs can be fulfilled. If this is something that cannot be built as a plugin
column14: then please provide more information about why in order to keep this issue open. This issue will automatically be closed in two months if no further activity occurs. Thank you for all your contributions.'"

b"b' Cache converted markdown'"

b'b" **Problem:** Much of a site\'s generation time is spent converting Markdown.  **Assumption:** Markdown converters are trivially deterministic.  **Proposed solution:** Cache rendered Markdown.  Given a blob of raw Markdown
column11: we hash the blob and see if this blob as already been converted. If it has been
column12: we can return the cached HTML. If it has not
column13: we will convert it like normal
column14: and then save the output to our cache.  ~~This is simply using the filesystem as a cache. The hash of the raw Markdown is the filename
column15: and the file contains the converted Markdown.~~  Since Markdown converters are trivially deterministic
column16: none of this depends on the state of the site
column17: and can be totally separate from incremental regeneration.  ~~This is absolutely related to #7158
column18: which will clear the cache on  . Once that is merged
column19: this should be updated to use instead of hardcoding  ~~  Looking at Utterson
column20: some sites (like url  or url  can have their build time reduced by a third with a warm Markdown cache."'

column10: b"b' Tests are failing because cache is not invalidated when kramdown options are changed.  It would be easy to add a step in those two tests to flush the cache
column11: but this brings up an important point that we need to communicate this caching to users
column12: so they are not confused if they change their Markdown options but nothing changes on the generated site.'"

column10: b"b' Interesting! This performs a number of disk operations
column11: which can be slow on spinning disks especially. Did you explore an in-memory LRU cache that you can commit to disk?  Updating your markdown converter  its settings should definitely invalidate the cache. Also if it used liquid
column12: it may generate different markdown in different runs so make sure the cache key is liquid-agnostic (either by using the compiled liquid as the hash content
column13: or by ensuring the cached html has the unrendered liquid in it).  A Cache or DiskCache class could be helpful here too! Using git\\xe2\\x80\\x99s method of storing the files could help too
column14: i.e. _... (subdirectories to Prevent common file system issues around too many files in one directory etc)'"

column10: b'b\'  This was primarily meant to make sure that some sort of caching could significantly improve performance. It seems that it can
column11: especially since Utterson is using a spinning disk backed EBS which has very limited I/O performance as you mention. Fortunately
column12: Markdown converters don\\\'t need to know anything about Liquid. Since Jekyll processes Liquid before Markdown conversion
column13: any change at the Liquid level would result in different raw Markdown. As you say
column14: we are "using the compiled liquid as the hash content". I think that Jekyll providing a unified caching mechanism is a great idea. This way
column15: plugins could provide different caching backends. It might be worth implementing a Jekyll cache in a different PR
column16: then updating this PR to use that cache. :+1:\''

column10: b"b' I have updated this PR so that it uses the caching mechanism from #7169. This
column11: of course
column12: makes the diff _much_ cleaner.'"

column10: b'b" This PR no longer uses its own caching mechanism
column11: but uses Jekyll\'s built-in cache system."'

b'b" @sarahfang9292 Thanks for the quick reply. It looks like you will need to create a subdirectory for your Jekyll site.  Right now
column11: you are trying to run inside your home directory. This means that Jekyll is trying to process every file that you have access to
column12: including applications that you\'ve installed. This is a problem.  Instead
column13: you will want to create a site inside your home directory. Since Jekyll is already installed
column14: you can run to create a new Jekyll site. Then you can change into the created directory with and run again from there. When done this way
column15: Jekyll will only process files in instead of everything in your home directory.  I believe you should be able to find more detail about getting started with Jekyll in our [quick-start guide]url  \\xe2\\x98\\xba\\xef\\xb8\\x8f"'

column10: b"b' @pathawks It works now. Thanks!'"

b'b" I have spent my entire evening on this Issue. I wiped my dev environment and started completely from scratch! I ran in to some permissions issues early on this time around but I managed to solve it. \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x84  ## Install Xcode Command Line Tools  1. Install the Xcode Command Line Tools using your Terminal app.    2. You will get a prompt and have to click the button.   (We don\'t need Xcode ignore option ).  3. You may need to install the macOS SDK headers (Xcode comes with the current version\'s headers).   Next we Install [Homebrew]url  a package manager for macOS.  **Why?**  We will use Homebrew to install rbenv. **Why macOS already comes with a version of Ruby?**  A lot of the system directories in macOS are locked down making it unusable so we will use rbenv to manage Ruby.  ## Install Homebrew 1. Install Homebrew by entering the following command in your Terminal app and hitting the RETURN key.   2. You will now be prompted to hit the RETURN key again to continue.  Output:   3. You will be prompted to enter your Admin Password to allow the install to continue.  Output:   The Homebrew install will continue.  Output:   As you can see we have now installed Homebrew successfully. ## Install rbenv 1. Install rbenv with the following command using Homebrew.  Output:   2. Set up rbenv in your shell.   Output:  3. You can add the above line manually or run the following command to update your file.  4. Close your Terminal window and open a new one so your changes take effect.  5. Verify that rbenv is properly set up using this rbenv-doctor script:   Output:  6. You can now list all available version of Ruby using  .  7. Let\'s install the latest stable release which is currently as of writing.   Output:   8. List all Ruby versions known to rbenv  Output:  9. Set the global version of Ruby.   10. Confirm your global version of Ruby is set.  Output:  ## Install Bundler  1. Installing [Bundler]url  provides a consistent environment for Ruby projects by tracking and installing the exact gems and versions that are needed.   Output:  ## Installing Jekyll  1. Finally it\'s time to install Jekyll.  2. Check the Jekyll version.  Done! \\xf0\\x9f\\xa4\\x9e ## How to update Jekyll  Bundler will update all your gems to the latest versions by simply running in a Terminal window. Did you find this tutorial helpful?"'

b"b' Collection assets still output even when output:false'"

b'b\' ## My Environment  | Software   | Version(s)  Operating System |  OSX 10.14.1   3.8.5  No   |  A collection is defined in _ and the output suppressed:  I have a mixture of images and markdown pages inside the _my_collection folder.  ## Expected Behaviour  I expect all content in that collection to not be output
column11: including assets like images. I understand there is a complex behaviour around _posts for historical reasons
column12: however I\\\'m only talking about custom collections here.  ## Current Behavior  All markdown pages are suppressed
column13: but other files go to the output. If the flag was called "page_output: false" then this would make sense
column14: but the flag is just "output: false" which would lead me to believe we should be able to disable the whole collection at will.  \''

column10: b"b' May I ask why you want to put images in a collection rather than in another folder?  All the info I read indicates that a collection folder is treated the same as any other folder; the contents will be replicated to the _site folder. But adding a collection to _ just instructs Jekyll to process any markdown files in that folder in a special manner. '"
b'b" Yep
column11: collections whether it\'s or another are only accepting Markdown files by default. If you don\'t want your assets to be output you need to put them in a folder beginning with an underscore that is not a collection or exclude the folder from the build."'

column10: b'b\'  This is wrong. Collections other than can contain static files along side the Markdown "documents"\''

column10: b"b' This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least two months. The resources of the Jekyll team are limited
column11: and so we are asking for your help. If this is a **bug** and you can still reproduce this error on the latest 3.x-stable or master branch
column12: please reply with all of the information you have about it in order to keep the issue open. If this is a **feature request**
column13: please consider building it first as a plugin. Jekyll 3 introduced [hooks]url  which provide convenient access points throughout the Jekyll build pipeline whereby most needs can be fulfilled. If this is something that cannot be built as a plugin
column14: then please provide more information about why in order to keep this issue open. This issue will automatically be closed in two months if no further activity occurs. Thank you for all your contributions.'"

column10: b'b" I\'m sure I\'m being a bit daft here but it\'s not clear to me why you\'d need to know that a file exists. Could you provide a few example use cases for us to consider? Thanks!"'
b'b\' One of the cases I am interested in is the following: we are managing a bunch of research  with a single Jekyll instance. Each gets its own subfolder
column11: with a few files using templates. One of the files generates a table of contents for that workshop
column12: listing all the assets in it (say: "Schedule"
column13: Participants
column14:
Registration"). But some assets should only show up if they are really present, e.g. "Group photo" should only be shown after a file has been added.  Of course in that case, I could just as well set a boolean in the top YAML of the index file which indicates whether to include the group photo or not. But this is easy to forget; and more so if you consider that this has to be done for several files. Anything that the computer can trivially do automatically removes a chance for errors.\''

column11: just released yesterday)  Latest (v0.3.1) |   ## Expected Behaviour  A normal build without the warning:  .  ## Current Behavior  Hi
column12: we have a Jekyll theme build for our own Jekyll sites on a separate repo accessed thru [jekyll-remote-theme]url  and all have been working just fine until yesterday that we upgraded from to (based on the Github [pages-gem v198]url  release).  When using Jekyll
column13: there is a warning showing us:
column14: this warning goes away if Jekyll is downgraded to  .  The warning isn\'t affecting us because the folder **does exists** on the Jekyll theme repo and all SCSS files are precompiled just fine. We think that this warning is telling us that the folder doesn\'t exist on the main repo but that it\'s expected and it shouldn\'t produce any warning.  ![Screen Shot 2019-04-24 at 12 15 56 PM]url What do you suggest? "'

column10: b"b' Further reading...  It seems that the warning message was introduced in #5195 to offer useful debug information when needed but
column11: in this case... it is throwing false positives when using [-remote-theme]url  plugin.'"

column10: b"b' @cetinajero So that means this message does not reflect an error?'"
b'b"  @moritzschaefer No. It\'s just a *warning* that the theme you\'re using doesn\'t have directory at the root of your current theme. Warnings are in yellow.. Errors are in red.. "'
b"b' @DirtyF is not exactly a user-friendly warning. We could be a bit more verbose..'"
b'b" @ashmaroli Than you
column11: I agree; the warning is confusing. It implies there is something that needs correcting.  I\'ve just encountered this after upgrading to jekyll 3.8 (via github-pages 198)
column12: for a theme that does not have a folder. Why is this a warning? What consequence is there for not including a folder in a theme?"'

column10: b'b\'  Exactly @moritzschaefer
column11: isn\\\'t something to worry about too much. @ashmaroli
column12: in my case **there is** a directory at the root of my
column13: you can see it [here]url My theory is that the warning is showing _before_ the [jekyll-remote-theme]url  plugin has fetch the contents of the remote theme and
column14: therefore... the directory doesn\\\'t exist just yet.  I have added a logger to the function like so:   And this is the output that I get:   Please note that the is logged twice:  The first one goes to the **rescue** ( ) because the directory doesn\\\'t exist just yet.  The second one (after the "Remote Theme: Using theme -theme-marketing" message) doesn\\\'t fails because the contents of the has been fetched.  At least... that\\\'s my theory haha...  Will I be right @ashmaroli?\''

column10: b'b"  Not much really
column11: you can use plain _CSS_ and all be good
column12: but... it\'s better to write all your style using _SASS_ partials @ellemenno. "'

column10: b'b\' Errors are in red..  I consider myself an experienced user and I wouldn\\\'t have caught the color of the message meaning "warning". I\\\'m not sure that\\\'s the most accessible way to convey the importance
column11: or lack thereof.  What I do see is **invalid theme folder** I wouldn\\\'t have an issue with it staying a warning
column12: but maybe changing the message to something more inline with the issue. I think we\\\'re at a time and place that Jekyll shouldn\\\'t force Sass on development. I\\\'m using PostCSS for partials among other optimizations. I\\\'m not suggesting dropping support
column13: just not make assumption it\\\'s the only way to process styling files.  \''

column10: b'b"  @cetinajero Looks like you\'re right indeed. Good job with the investigation. @miklb I agree with you as well. The logged message isn\'t entirely accurate
column11: (and based on comments in this thread
column12: the message can also be misleading in a certain situation.. :man_shrugging: )"'

column10: b'b"  Thanks @ashmaroli! I really don\'t know how to solve it nor why the is triggered _before_ and _after_ the fetch
column11: but.. if you give me a North... I could try to put together a PR for review."'

column10: b'b\' @cetinajero We won\\\'t be able to "fix" here.  Regarding the dubious log message from Jekyll
column11: we can ***adapt*** from another method of the same class: url \''

column10: b"b' Hmmm... I was thinking something more complex like checking if the entire root directory was empty... then skip the warning and wait for the second check

column10: b'b" Don\'t read symlinks in  in safe mode"'
b"b' This is a :warning: security fix.  ## Summary  As a result of #7188
column11: any entry in that points to a file within the is read-in during a build. That created a ** ** issue where an entry referring to a symlink is read-in even if it points to an entity outside the  .  ~~This PR attempts to resolve that by mirroring without creating a new instance.~~'"

column10: b"b' Why is the filtering here and not in  ?'"
b'b"  I didn\'t want to create a new instance to do something possible with just native Ruby. But I guess its more in line with OOP principles than duplicating logic. So I\'ve made the change."'

b'b" I\'m so sorry. I didn\'t do a good job of describing what I wanted. My original thought is that there could be a method in that is a class method. That would keep the symlink logic isolated to and keep from having to allocate an object just for the symlink check."'
